name: 3/4 Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Place your hands lightly behind your head or across your chest.
Engage your abs to lift your shoulders and upper back off the floor.
Lower yourself back down with control, stopping before your lower back lifts off the floor.
form_cues: Lead with your chest, not your head.
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your hands.
Using momentum instead of abdominal control.
Letting your lower back arch off the floor too much on the descent.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel any strain in your lower back, reduce your range of motion or place your hands behind you for support.

name: 90/90 Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on your back with one leg extended straight on the floor.
Lift your other leg up, keeping the knee bent at 90 degrees.
Gently straighten the lifted leg towards the ceiling until you feel a stretch in the hamstring.
Return to the bent position and repeat.
form_cues: Keep your lower back pressed into the floor.
Stop at the point of a comfortable stretch, not pain.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the floor to chase the stretch.
Jerking the leg straight instead of moving smoothly.
Bending the extended leg on the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Never force a stretch; if you feel sharp pain, stop immediately.

name: Machine Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and place your feet under the pads.
Grab the handles and rest your triceps on the pads.
Crunch down by bringing your elbows toward your knees.
Return to the starting position slowly.
common_mistakes: Using your arms to pull instead of your abs to crunch.
Using too much weight, causing you to jerk.
Not controlling the negative (return) portion of the lift.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a very light weight to master the form first.

name: Adductor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down and place a foam roller under one inner thigh.
Support your weight with your hands and knees.
Slowly roll from your hip down to just above your knee.
Pause for 10-30 seconds on any tight spots.
form_cues: Avoid rolling directly over bony areas.
common_mistakes: Rolling too fast without pausing on tension spots.
Putting too much weight and causing bruising.
Rolling over the knee joint itself.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel sharp nerve pain, adjust your position or reduce pressure.

name: Adductor/Groin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back and bring the soles of your feet together, letting your knees fall out to the sides.
If you have a partner, have them gently hold your feet.
Try to squeeze your knees together while your partner resists for 10 seconds.
Relax and let your partner gently push your knees further apart to stretch.
form_cues: Keep your back flat on the floor.
Communicate with your partner about intensity.
common_mistakes: Letting your partner push too hard, causing pain.
Lifting your hips off the floor.
Holding your breath during the contraction.
injury_prevention_tips: Only perform this with a trusted partner who understands how to apply gradual pressure.

name: Air Bike
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with hands lightly behind your head.
Lift your knees to a 90-degree angle and lift your shoulders off the floor.
Bring your right elbow toward your left knee while extending the right leg.
Switch sides in a smooth pedaling motion.
form_cues: Keep your lower back pressed to the floor.
Exhale as you twist to bring elbow to knee.
common_mistakes: Rushing the movement and losing form.
Letting the lower back arch off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: If your neck gets tired, place one hand behind your head and the other on your stomach.

name: All Fours Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your hands and knees on a comfortable surface.
Shift your weight to one side and grab your opposite foot with your hand.
Gently pull your heel toward your glute.
Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.
form_cues: Squeeze your glute to intensify the stretch.
common_mistakes: Letting the knee flare out to the side.
injury_prevention_tips: Place a mat under your knees for comfort.

name: Alternate Hammer Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing your body.
Curl one dumbbell up toward your shoulder without moving your upper arm.
Lower it down with control.
Repeat with the other arm, alternating sides.
form_cues: Keep your elbows tucked by your sides.
Squeeze at the top of the movement.
common_mistakes: Swinging your body to lift the weight.
Moving your elbows forward or backward.
Dropping the weight quickly on the way down.
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a weight that allows you to maintain strict form.

name: Alternate Heel Touchers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Crunch your upper body up slightly.
Reach your right hand to touch your right heel.
Return to center and repeat on the left side.
form_cues: Keep your head in line with your spine.
Keep your shoulders lifted throughout the set.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: If you can't reach your heel comfortably, just reach as far as your range of motion allows.

name: Alternating Deltoid Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding light dumbbells at your sides.
Raise one arm to the front to shoulder height.
Lower it and then raise the other arm out to the side to shoulder height.
Continue alternating between front and side raises.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow.
common_mistakes: Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weights (1-3 lbs) to learn the movement.

name: Alternating Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent.
Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in each hand at chest level.
Press one weight up until your arm is straight.
Lower it back down and press the other side.
form_cues: Keep your elbows at a 45-degree angle to your body.
common_mistakes: Banging the weight down on your chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your feet flat on the floor to stabilize your spine.

name: Ankle Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding onto a stable object for balance.
Lift one foot slightly off the ground.
Rotate your ankle in a circle, drawing it with your big toe.
Complete the reps on one side before switching.
form_cues: Keep your balance by holding on tight.
common_mistakes: Moving the entire leg instead of just the ankle.
Going too fast and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: Do this near a wall or sturdy chair to prevent falling.

name: Ankle On The Knee
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet on the floor.
Cross your right ankle over your left knee.
Grab the back of your left thigh and gently pull both legs toward your chest.
Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your head and shoulders relaxed.
Keep your back flat on the floor.
Pull gently until you feel a stretch.
common_mistakes: Pulling too hard and causing knee pain.
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel knee pain, stop immediately.

name: Anterior Tibialis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs bent.
Place a foam roller or rolling pin on the muscle outside your shin.
Gently roll from just below the knee to above the ankle.
Pause on any tight spots for 10-30 seconds.
form_cues: Use your hands to support your weight.
common_mistakes: Putting too much body weight on the roller.
injury_prevention_tips: This area is sensitive; use light pressure to start.

name: Arm Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with your arms extended straight out to your sides.
Make small circles with your arms for 10 seconds.
Reverse the direction of the circles.
Keep your core engaged throughout.
form_cues: Keep arms parallel to the floor.
Keep a slight bend in the elbows.
common_mistakes: Making circles that are too large and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: If you have shoulder pain, reduce the size of the circles.

name: Back Flyes - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a resistance band to a sturdy post.
Stand facing away from the post, holding the band handles.
Start with arms extended in front of you.
Pull your arms out to the sides and back, squeezing your shoulder blades.
form_cues: Keep arms straight but not locked.
Squeeze your back muscles at the end of the movement.
common_mistakes: Using too heavy a band and losing form.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the band is securely anchored before starting.

name: Ball Leg Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your heels on top of a stability ball.
Lift your hips off the ground.
Roll the ball toward you by bending your knees.
Roll it back out to the starting position.
common_mistakes: Letting hips drop to the floor.
Lifting hips with your glutes instead of hamstrings.
Moving too fast and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the ball is the correct size so your knees are at 90 degrees at the top.

name: Band Hip Adductions
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a band to a sturdy post.
Stand sideways to the post with the band around your far ankle.
Keep your leg straight and pull it across your body.
Return to the start slowly.
form_cues: Control the movement on the way back.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the leg.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light band to avoid losing balance.

name: Band Pull Apart
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a resistance band with both hands, arms straight out in front.
Pull the band apart by moving your hands out to the sides.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together.
Return to the start with control.
common_mistakes: Using a band that is too heavy, causing you to round your shoulders forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Focus on posture; this is a great exercise to counteract slouching.

name: Band Skullcrusher
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a band behind you (e.g., under a bench or rack).
Lie down and hold the band ends with hands near your forehead.
Keep elbows pointing to the ceiling and tucked in.
Extend your arms straight up, then lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep elbows pointing up, not flaring out.
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out to the sides.
Using too much weight, causing elbow pain.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel elbow pain, switch to a lighter band or try a different tricep exercise.

name: Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart.
Keep your elbows pinned to your sides.
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders.
Lower it back down slowly.
form_cues: Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Swinging your body to lift the weight.
Letting elbows drift forward or backward.
Using a grip that is too wide or too narrow.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid swinging to protect your lower back and bicep tendons.

name: Barbell Glute Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with a padded barbell across your hips.
Lie back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Drive through your heels to lift your hips toward the ceiling.
Lower your hips back down with control.
form_cues: Squeeze your glutes hard at the top.
common_mistakes: Overextending your lower back (arching too much).
Pushing through toes instead of heels.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a thick pad or towel under the bar to prevent bruising on your hips.

name: Barbell Seated Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with the balls of your feet on a block or step.
Place a barbell across your upper thighs (near the knees).
Hold the bar in place with your hands.
Raise your heels up as high as possible, then lower slowly.
form_cues: Pause at the top for a squeeze.
common_mistakes: Bouncing at the bottom of the movement.
Moving your knees up and down.
Letting the bar roll off your legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bar is secure and balanced before starting.

name: Barbell Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip.
Keep your arms straight and relaxed.
Shrug your shoulders up toward your ears.
Lower them back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your neck in a neutral position.
common_mistakes: Rolling your shoulders forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid heavy weights initially to prevent neck strain.

name: Barbell Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell behind your neck or resting on your shoulders.
Keep your torso straight.
Bend sideways to the right as far as you can.
Return to center and repeat on the left side.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing loss of balance.
injury_prevention_tips: Start without weight to master the movement pattern first.

name: Behind Head Chest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with a partner behind you.
Place your hands behind your head with elbows pointing out.
Have your partner gently hold your elbows while you try to pull them forward (isometric).
Relax, and let your partner slowly pull your elbows back for a stretch.
form_cues: Stop if you feel sharp pain.
common_mistakes: Partner pulling too hard or too fast.
injury_prevention_tips: Never force a stretch past comfort.
Ensure your partner watches your facial cues for discomfort.

name: Bench Dips
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the edge of a bench and place hands next to hips.
Slide your butt off the bench and walk feet out.
Bend elbows to lower your body, then push back up.
Keep knees bent to make it easier.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel shoulder pain, stop immediately.
Keep feet close to your body to reduce load.

name: Band Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench with a band looped under your feet.
Hold the band handles at chest level.
Press hands straight up toward the ceiling.
Lower hands slowly back to chest.
common_mistakes: Letting bands pull arms inward (losing tension).
injury_prevention_tips: Check band integrity for tears before use.
Use a stable bench surface.

name: Bent-Knee Hip Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet off the floor.
Pull knees toward your chest using your abs.
Lift hips off the floor and roll pelvis back.
Lower hips back down slowly.
common_mistakes: Letting feet touch the floor during the set.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep movements slow and controlled.
Avoid if you have existing lower back pain.

name: Body Tricep Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Find a bar at chest height (like a Smith machine).
Stand facing away, holding the bar with hands shoulder-width.
Step feet forward and lean your body forward.
Bend elbows to lower chest to bar, then push back up.
common_mistakes: Going too close to the bar (harder)
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bar is locked in place.
Don't let your nose crash into the bar.

name: Bodyweight Mid Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with an overhand grip.
Lift knees to chest and lean back.
Pull your chest toward the bar using your back.
Lower yourself back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep arms straight at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you can safely hang from the bar.
Don't let go of the bar at the bottom (controlled descent).

name: Bodyweight Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Sit your hips back and down (like a chair).
Go as low as you can comfortably.
Stand back up by driving through heels.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced.
Ensure you have adequate ankle mobility.

name: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with hands on hips.
Step forward with one leg and lower hips.
Drop back knee toward the ground.
Push off front foot to step into the next lunge.
injury_prevention_tips: Perform on a soft surface if balance is poor.
Don't let the back knee slam into the floor.

name: Brachialis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller under your upper arm.
Support your weight with your hand and feet.
Roll from the elbow toward the shoulder.
Pause on tender spots for 10-30 seconds.
common_mistakes: Rolling directly over the elbow joint.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid rolling over bone.
Don't spend too long on one spot.

name: Butt-Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a forearm plank position.
Arch your lower back slightly.
Squeeze abs to lift hips toward the ceiling.
Lower hips back down slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep tension in the core throughout.
Avoid if you have wrist pain.

name: Butt Lift (Bridge)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Drive through heels to lift hips up.
Squeeze glutes at the top.
Lower hips back down slowly.
common_mistakes: Pushing through toes instead of heels.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep glutes tight at the top to protect the back.
Ensure feet are hip-width apart.

name: Machine Chest Fly
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine with back against the pad.
Grab the handles with arms slightly bent.
Bring handles together in front of chest.
Return slowly to the start position.
common_mistakes: Opening arms too far back (shoulder strain).
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go past shoulder level.
Control the weight on the way back.

name: Cable Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit between two cable towers.
Hold handles at chest height, elbows bent.
Press handles forward until arms are straight.
Bring handles back slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a weight you can control.
Keep wrists straight.

name: Cable Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel in front of a high cable with a rope attachment.
Hold rope behind your head.
Crunch down, bringing elbows toward knees.
Return up slowly against the weight.
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms instead of abs.
injury_prevention_tips: Pad your knees if the floor is hard.
Keep tension on abs, not lower back.

name: Cable Hammer Curls (Rope Attachment)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach rope to a low cable.
Stand straight and hold rope with neutral grip.
Curl rope up toward shoulders.
Lower rope slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep upper arms glued to your sides.
Don't drop the weight suddenly.

name: Cable Hip Adduction
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach ankle cuff to low cable.
Stand sideways to the machine.
Grab the machine for balance.
Pull working leg across the standing leg.
common_mistakes: Using hip flexor instead of adductor.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight.
Ensure ankle cuff is secure.

name: Cable Internal Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit next to a low cable.
Hold handle with elbow bent 90 degrees.
Keep elbow tucked into your side.
Rotate forearm across your stomach.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up shoulders first.
Avoid if you have rotator cuff pain.

name: Cable Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench facing a low cable.
Hold the bar attachment with arms extended.
Curl the bar up toward shoulders.
Lower the bar slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend elbows at the bottom.
Use a light weight to start.

name: Cable Rear Delt Fly
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cables above head height.
Cross arms in front of you.
Pull arms back and out to the sides.
Return arms forward slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the weight slam back.
Keep wrists neutral.

name: Cable Rope Rear-Delt Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a low row machine with a rope.
Lean back slightly, arms extended.
Pull rope to upper chest, elbows wide.
Return arms forward slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep neck neutral.
Don't jerk the weight.

name: Cable Seated Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench facing away from a high cable.
Hold rope behind head.
Crunch down, bringing elbows to knees.
Return up slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Pad knees if needed.
Keep tension on abs.

name: Cable Seated Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench between two low cables.
Cross arms in front of you.
Raise arms to the sides until parallel to floor.
Lower arms slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go too heavy.
Keep wrists neutral.

name: Cable Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cables to bottom position.
Stand between towers, hold handles at shoulders.
Press handles straight overhead.
Lower handles back to shoulders.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep core braced.
Don't lock elbows out hard.

name: Cable Shrugs
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a cable bar attached to a low pulley.
Stand tall with arms straight down.
Shrug shoulders up to ears.
Lower shoulders back down.
form_cues: Hold at the top for 1 second.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep chin tucked slightly.
Don't jerk the weight.

name: Cable Wrist Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench, hold cable bar with palms up.
Rest forearms on thighs, wrists hanging off.
Curl wrists up toward you.
Lower wrists back down slowly.
common_mistakes: Dropping the weight at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to avoid wrist strain.
Don't hyperextend wrists.

name: Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand inside the machine with the pads resting on your shoulders.
Keep your chest up and arms straight at your sides.
Shrug your shoulders straight up toward your ears.
Lower slowly back to the start.
common_mistakes: Rolling shoulders forward or backward instead of moving straight up and down.
Using too much weight and swinging the torso.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck in a neutral position; don't crane it forward.

name: Calf Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the machine and adjust the seat so your knees are slightly bent.
Place the balls of your feet on the lower part of the platform.
Push down through your toes to lift the weight, extending your ankles.
Lower the weight slowly until you feel a stretch.
common_mistakes: Moving knees instead of just ankles.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't lock your knees hard at the top; keep a slight bend.

name: Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the leg press and place your feet on the platform with heels hanging off.
Press the platform up until legs are straight (do not lock knees).
Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels high.
Lower heels slowly below the platform for a stretch.
common_mistakes: Moving knees up and down instead of keeping them still.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep safety bars engaged if available.

name: Calf Raise On A Dumbbell
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a sturdy object for balance.
Stand on a single dumbbell with the balls of your feet.
Raise your heels by pressing up on your toes.
Lower slowly to stretch the calves.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a stable surface to hold onto.
Start with light weight to master balance.

name: Calf Raises - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the middle of a resistance band.
Hold the handles at shoulder height with palms forward.
Press up onto your toes, lifting heels high.
Lower heels slowly to feel tension.
common_mistakes: Standing on the ends of the band (causes slipping).
injury_prevention_tips: Check that the band is not frayed before use.

name: Calf Stretch Elbows Against Wall
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a wall, about arm's length away.
Place your forearms on the wall.
Step one foot back, keeping the heel flat.
Lean forward gently until you feel a stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep hips facing forward.

name: Calf Stretch Hands Against Wall
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a wall, about arm's length away.
Step one foot back, keeping the heel flat.
Place hands on the wall and lean forward.
Keep your back straight and hips forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the back leg straight but not locked.

name: Calves-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with legs extended.
Place a foam roller under your lower leg.
Lift hips slightly to add pressure.
Roll slowly from knee to ankle.
common_mistakes: Rolling directly over the knee or ankle joint.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid rolling over bones; focus on muscle.

name: Cat Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get on hands and knees.
Inhale and drop your belly slightly.
Exhale and round your spine up toward the ceiling.
Drop your head and hold.
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly and smoothly.

name: Chair Leg Extended Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright in a chair.
Extend one leg straight out in front.
Flex your foot (toes up).
Hold gently, then switch legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Only extend to a mild stretch.

name: Chair Lower Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit tall in a chair.
Reach one arm over your head to the opposite side.
Gently lean until you feel a stretch.
Hold, then switch sides.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep shoulders relaxed.

name: Chair Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand in front of a chair with feet shoulder-width.
Push hips back and bend knees to lower to the chair.
Lightly tap the seat (don't fully sit).
Stand back up by driving through heels.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a higher chair if mobility is limited.

name: Chair Upper Body Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the edge of a chair.
Grip the back of the chair with both hands.
Straighten arms and gently lean forward.
Hold and breathe.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral.

name: Chest And Front Of Shoulder Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a stick or broomstick with a wide grip.
Raise it overhead and behind your head.
Keep arms straight.
Stop when you feel a stretch in the chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not force the stick behind your head if it hurts.

name: Chest Stretch on Stability Ball
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a stability ball.
Place one elbow on the ball.
Gently lower your chest toward the floor.
Hold, then switch sides.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the shoulder away from the ear.

name: Child's Pose
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on hands and knees.
Sit your hips back toward your heels.
Extend arms forward and lower chest.
Rest forehead on the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Place a cushion under knees or ankles if sensitive.

name: Chin To Chest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit tall with a straight back.
Place hands behind your head.
Gently lower chin toward chest.
Hold and breathe.
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly to avoid neck strain.

name: Close-Grip EZ Bar Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold an EZ bar with a close grip (hands inside shoulder width).
Stand tall with elbows tucked at your sides.
Curl the bar up toward shoulders.
Lower slowly to full extension.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral to avoid strain.

name: Close-Grip Front Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the lat pulldown with a close grip.
Pull the bar down to your upper chest.
Squeeze shoulder blades together.
Return slowly to the start.
common_mistakes: Yanking the bar behind the neck.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement controlled; avoid momentum.

name: Close-Grip Standing Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell with hands shoulder-width or slightly inside.
Stand tall with elbows pinned to your sides.
Curl the bar up to shoulder height.
Lower slowly to full extension.
common_mistakes: Using hips to swing the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral.

name: Concentration Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench, hold a dumbbell in one hand.
Place the back of your upper arm against your inner thigh.
Curl the dumbbell up toward your shoulder.
Lower slowly and repeat on the other side.
common_mistakes: Lifting the elbow off the thigh.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter weight to focus on form.

name: Cross-Body Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Place hands behind your head.
Bring right elbow toward left knee while lifting left knee.
Alternate sides with each rep.
common_mistakes: Moving only the elbows without torso rotation.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep neck neutral; don't yank head forward.

name: Cross Body Hammer Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells with palms facing in.
Curl the right dumbbell toward your left shoulder.
Lower and repeat on the other side.
Keep elbows close to your body.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral.

name: Crunch - Hands Overhead
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Reach arms overhead with palms crossed.
Curl your chest toward your hips.
Lower slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep chin slightly tucked.

name: Crunches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Place hands lightly by your head (don't lock fingers).
Press lower back into the floor.
Lift shoulder blades a few inches, then lower.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep elbows wide and relaxed.

name: Dancer's Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your right leg crossed over your left, keeping the right knee bent.
Keep your left leg straight and flat on the floor.
Place your left elbow on your right knee and your right hand on the floor for support.
Gently rotate your upper body to the right until you feel a stretch. Hold, then switch sides.
common_mistakes: Hunching the back instead of rotating through the spine.
Using too much force and bouncing.
injury_prevention_tips: Focus on a smooth rotation rather than forcing the twist.
Keep the supporting leg straight to stabilize the hip.

name: Dead Bug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with arms extended toward the ceiling and knees bent at 90 degrees.
Exhale hard to press your lower back flat against the floor.
Slowly lower one leg toward the floor while keeping your back flat.
Return to the start and repeat on the other side.
common_mistakes: Letting your lower back arch off the floor.
Moving too fast and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: If your back arches, don't lower your leg as far.
Keep your ribcage down to prevent flaring.

name: Decline Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs on a decline bench and lie back.
Place hands lightly by your head, elbows wide.
Press your lower back into the bench and lift your shoulders slightly.
Squeeze your abs at the top, then lower slowly.
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your hands.
Using momentum to lift your shoulders.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a tennis ball's space between your chin and chest.
Stop if you feel strain in your lower back.

name: Decline Oblique Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure your legs on a decline bench and lie back.
Place one hand behind your head and the other on your thigh.
Crunch up and rotate your torso to bring your elbow toward the opposite knee.
Lower slowly and complete all reps on one side before switching.
common_mistakes: Yanking your neck to force the twist.
Moving your hips side to side.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement controlled to protect the spine.
Use a lighter weight if available to focus on form.

name: Decline Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on a decline bench and hold the top for support.
Lift your legs until they are parallel to the floor.
Curl your hips up toward your chest, lifting your butt off the bench.
Lower your hips back down with control.
common_mistakes: Swinging your legs to create momentum.
Letting your hips drop too quickly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a slight bend in the knees to reduce hip flexor strain.
Move slowly to keep tension on the abs.

name: Machine Dips
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit in the dip machine and grip the handles.
Keep your elbows tucked in close to your sides.
Push the handles down until your arms are straight.
Return to the starting position slowly.
common_mistakes: Locking elbows hard at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let your shoulders shrug up.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows at the bottom.

name: Dumbbell Alternate Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward.
Curl one dumbbell up toward your shoulder while keeping your elbow stationary.
Squeeze your bicep at the top, then lower slowly.
Alternate arms for each rep.
common_mistakes: Lifting the elbow away from the body.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a weight you can control without rocking your torso.
Keep your wrists straight.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with dumbbells at your chest, palms forward.
Press the dumbbells straight up until your arms are extended.
Squeeze your chest at the top.
Lower the weights slowly back to the start.
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows to 90 degrees (keep them at ~45).
Bouncing the weights off your chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulder blades pulled together and down.
Don't fully lock out your elbows.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press with Neutral Grip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells with palms facing each other.
Press the weights straight up over your chest.
Squeeze your chest at the top.
Lower slowly until the dumbbells are near your ribs.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral to protect joints.
Shoulder blades should stay retracted.

name: Dumbbell Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward.
Curl both dumbbells up toward your shoulders.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
Lower the weights slowly back to the start.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your upper arms vertical and stationary.
Use a weight that allows strict form.

name: Dumbbell Incline Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lean your chest against an incline bench, holding dumbbells with arms straight down.
Pull the dumbbells up toward your hips by bending your elbows.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top.
Lower slowly to the start.
common_mistakes: Pulling with your arms instead of your back.
Lifting your chest off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Don't jerk the weight up.

name: Dumbbell Lunges
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides.
Step one foot forward and lower your hips until both knees are bent at 90 degrees.
Keep your front knee behind your toes.
Push back up to the start and switch legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let your front knee go past your toes.
Keep your core braced.

name: Dumbbell Lying Pronation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a bench with one arm hanging down, holding a light dumbbell.
Bend your elbow to 90 degrees with your upper arm parallel to the floor.
Rotate your forearm up until it's parallel to the floor.
Lower slowly back down.
injury_prevention_tips: Start very light to protect the elbow.
Move smoothly, no jerking.

name: Dumbbell Lying Supination
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side on a bench with one arm hanging down, holding a light dumbbell.
Bend your elbow to 90 degrees with your upper arm parallel to the floor.
Rotate your forearm up toward the ceiling until vertical.
Lower slowly back down.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a very light weight.
Keep the movement controlled.

name: Dumbbell Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing back.
Raise your arms out to the sides until they reach shoulder height.
Pause briefly at the top.
Lower slowly back down.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
Don't shrug your shoulders.

name: Dumbbell Rear Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides.
Step one foot backward and lower your hips until both knees are bent at 90 degrees.
Keep your torso upright and front shin vertical.
Push back up to the start and switch legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core tight.
Ensure your front knee doesn't go past your toes.

name: Dumbbell Scaption
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding light dumbbells at your sides, thumbs pointing up.
Raise your arms forward and slightly out to the side at a 30-degree angle.
Stop when your arms are parallel to the floor.
Lower slowly back down.
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weights.
Keep shoulders down, not shrugged.

name: Dumbbell Seated One-Leg Calf Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with one foot on a block and a dumbbell on your thigh.
Lower your heel as far as you can to stretch the calf.
Raise your toes up high to contract the calf.
Complete reps on one leg, then switch.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your foot straight ahead.
Don't rush the stretch.

name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support, dumbbells at shoulder height.
Press the dumbbells straight up until your arms are extended.
Squeeze your shoulders at the top.
Lower slowly back to shoulder height.
common_mistakes: Banging dumbbells together at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced.
Don't fully lock out your elbows.

name: Dumbbell Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing your body.
Shrug your shoulders up toward your ears.
Hold the squeeze at the top for a second.
Lower slowly back down.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Avoid jerky movements.

name: Dumbbell Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a dumbbell in one hand, other hand on hip.
Bend sideways at the waist toward the weighted side.
Keep your torso straight and don't lean forward.
Return to the start and complete reps on one side, then switch.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and twisting.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged.
Avoid over-stretching at the bottom.

name: Dumbbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold dumbbells at your sides, feet shoulder-width apart.
Sit your hips back and down until your thighs are parallel to the floor.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Push through your heels to stand back up.
common_mistakes: Lifting your heels off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let your knees go past your toes.
Keep your core braced throughout.

name: Dumbbell Squat To A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold dumbbells at your sides with a bench behind you.
Sit your hips back and down until you lightly touch the bench.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Stand back up without sitting fully on the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a stable bench.
Keep your weight in your heels.

name: Dumbbell Step Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold dumbbells at your sides and stand facing a step or bench.
Place one foot fully on the step.
Push through that heel to lift your body up onto the step.
Step back down and repeat on the same leg before switching.
injury_prevention_tips: Make sure the step is stable.
Keep your knee aligned with your foot.

name: Dynamic Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Swing your straight arms up in front of you.
Gradually increase the height of the swing with each rep.
Continue for 5-10 swings until your arms are overhead.
injury_prevention_tips: Move within a comfortable range.
Don't force the stretch.

name: Ab Roller
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on your knees with hands on the roller, creating a straight line from knees to head.
Engage your core by bracing your abs like you're about to be punched.
Slowly roll forward, only going as far as you can maintain a flat back.
Pull yourself back using your abs, not your hips.
form_cues: Don't let your lower back sag or round.
Pull with your abs, not your arms.
common_mistakes: Overextending and letting the lower back sag
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Starting too far forward causing early fatigue
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a shorter range of motion and gradually increase as you get stronger.
If you feel lower back pain, regress to a plank position.

name: Advanced Kettlebell Windmill
beginner_friendly_instructions: Press the kettlebell overhead with one arm, locking out your elbow.
Turn your feet 45 degrees away from the kettlebell side.
Push your hip back on the same side as the kettlebell while keeping eyes on the weight.
Lower down until your hand touches your shin or the floor, then drive back up.
form_cues: Keep the kettlebell locked out overhead.
Keep eyes on the kettlebell at all times.
Push your hip back, don't just bend sideways.
common_mistakes: Bending the arm holding the weight
Rounding the back instead of hinging at the hip
injury_prevention_tips: Master the standard kettlebell windmill before adding weight.
Only go as deep as your mobility allows without rounding your back.

name: Alternate Incline Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on an incline bench with dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward.
Curl one dumbbell up while keeping your elbow pinned to your side.
Squeeze your bicep at the top, then slowly lower back down.
Alternate arms for each rep.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight
Moving elbows forward during the curl
Lifting too heavy and compromising form
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulders back and down to avoid strain.
Don't fully relax at the bottom - maintain tension.

name: Alternating Cable Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cables low and grasp handles at shoulder height, palms forward.
Press one handle overhead while keeping the other at shoulder height.
Control the weight back down to shoulder level.
Alternate pressing with each arm.
form_cues: Don't arch your lower back excessively.
common_mistakes: Arching lower back to get weight up
Pressing at an angle instead of straight up
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a weight that allows full range of motion without pain.
Keep your ribcage down to prevent excessive arching.

name: Alternating Hang Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with kettlebells between your feet, hinge at hips.
Explosively extend hips and knees while pulling one kettlebell up.
Rotate your wrist and catch it at shoulder height.
Lower it back down and repeat with the other kettlebell.
form_cues: Keep the kettlebell close to your body.
common_mistakes: Using only arms instead of hip drive
Letting the kettlebell drift away from the body
Catching with a stiff knee and back
injury_prevention_tips: Master the hip hinge pattern before adding speed.
Start light to learn the movement pattern.

name: Alternating Kettlebell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean two kettlebells to shoulder height.
Press one overhead while keeping the other at shoulder height.
Lower it back down and immediately press with the other arm.
Continue alternating.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your ribcage down to protect your lower back.
Use a weight that allows full lockout without pain.

name: Alternating Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hinge at hips with kettlebells in front of you.
Row one kettlebell to your hip while keeping the other stable.
Lower it with control.
Alternate sides each rep.
form_cues: Pull with your back, not your arm.
Squeeze your shoulder blade at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a neutral spine throughout.
Don't pull too high - stop when your elbow passes your torso.

name: Alternating Renegade Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a push-up position with hands on kettlebells.
Keep your body straight and stable.
Row one kettlebell up to your hip while balancing on the other.
Lower it and repeat on the other side.
form_cues: Keep hips level with the floor.
Pull with your back, not your arm.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with dumbbells for more stability.
Widen your foot stance if you can't maintain stability.

name: Anti-Gravity Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on an incline bench with a barbell on the floor below.
Reach down and grab the bar with a pronated grip.
Pull the bar to your chest with a reverse curl motion.
Press the bar forward away from your head, then return.
form_cues: Keep your arms parallel to the ground.
common_mistakes: Lifting your head to look forward
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight to start.
Make sure the bench is stable before starting.

name: Arnold Dumbbell Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing you.
As you press up, rotate your palms to face forward.
At the top, your arms should be fully extended.
Reverse the rotation as you lower back down.
form_cues: Keep your back against the bench.
common_mistakes: Arching back to get weight up
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to master the rotation.
Keep your core braced to protect your spine.

name: Around The Worlds
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back holding one dumbbell with both hands.
Keep arms straight and lower the weight behind your head in an arc.
Bring it back up in the same arc to your chest.
Keep the movement smooth and controlled.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
Keep arms parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Dropping the weight too low (risk to shoulders)
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight.
Stop if you feel any shoulder pain.

name: Balance Board
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the balance board on a flat, stable surface.
Step onto the board with both feet.
Find your balance by making small adjustments.
Hold for the desired time.
common_mistakes: Standing too close to the edge
injury_prevention_tips: Have something stable nearby to grab if needed.
Start with short holds and build up.

name: Band Assisted Pull-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop a resistance band over the pull-up bar.
Place one knee or foot in the band.
Grab the bar with hands slightly wider than shoulders.
Pull yourself up until your chin is over the bar, then lower slowly.
form_cues: Pull your elbows down, not forward.
common_mistakes: Not going through full range of motion
injury_prevention_tips: Choose a band that gives enough assistance for full range.
Make sure the band is secure before starting.

name: Band Good Morning
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the middle of a band with feet hip-width.
Loop the ends behind your neck/shoulders.
Hinge at your hips, pushing them back while keeping legs almost straight.
Drive hips forward to return to standing.
form_cues: Push hips back, don't bend forward.
common_mistakes: Using your back instead of hips
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light band to master the hinge.
Keep a neutral spine throughout.

name: Band Good Morning (Pull Through)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a band low behind you.
Face away and loop the band over your neck/shoulders.
Hinge forward at hips to about 90 degrees.
Drive hips forward to return to standing.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the anchor point is secure.
Start with light resistance.

name: Dumbbell Skullcrusher
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding dumbbells above your chest, arms straight.
Bend your elbows to lower the weights toward your forehead.
Stop just before they touch your head.
Extend arms back up to starting position.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the dumbbells crash onto your head.
Keep wrists straight to avoid strain.

name: Barbell Ab Rollout
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a push-up position with hands on a loaded barbell.
Keep your core tight and hips high.
Roll the bar forward, extending your body.
Pull back using your abs, not your arms.
form_cues: Don't let your lower back sag.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a shorter range of motion.
If your back hurts, stop and regress.

name: Barbell Ab Rollout - On Knees
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel with hands on a loaded barbell.
Keep your core tight and back flat.
Roll the bar forward, extending your body.
Pull back using your abs.
form_cues: Keep a straight line from knees to head.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a shorter range of motion.
Use a pad under your knees for comfort.

name: Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench with feet flat on the floor.
Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Lower the bar to your mid-chest with control.
Press the bar back up to starting position.
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blades pulled together.
Don't bounce the bar off your chest.
common_mistakes: Lifting your butt off the bench
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or safety bars.
Keep wrists straight to avoid strain.

name: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on an incline bench holding a barbell with arms extended.
Keep your elbows stationary.
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders.
Lower it back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a lighter weight.
Keep your shoulders back and down.

name: Barbell Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width, bar over mid-foot.
Hinge at hips and grip the bar just outside legs.
Keep back flat, chest up, and drive through heels.
Stand tall with hips fully extended, then lower with control.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
common_mistakes: Starting with hips too low or too high
Letting the bar drift away from body
injury_prevention_tips: Never round your back - stop if you feel rounding.
Use a weight that allows perfect form.

name: Barbell Full Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bar on shoulders, feet shoulder-width apart.
Push hips back and bend knees to lower down.
Go as deep as you can while keeping your back straight.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep knees in line with toes.
Go to at least parallel depth.
injury_prevention_tips: Use safety bars in a squat rack.
Start with bodyweight to master form.

name: Barbell Guillotine Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on bench, grip bar slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Lower the bar to your neck area with control.
Keep elbows flared out.
Press back up to starting position.
injury_prevention_tips: This is an advanced variation - start light.
Consider using a spotter.
Avoid if you have shoulder issues.

name: Barbell Hack Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with barbell behind you, grip it with arms extended.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Squat down by bending knees and hips.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your legs.
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from body
injury_prevention_tips: Use wrist wraps if grip is weak.
Start light to master the movement pattern.

name: Barbell Hip Thrust
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with your upper back against a bench.
Place a barbell across your hips.
Drive your hips up toward the ceiling.
Squeeze glutes at the top, then lower with control.
common_mistakes: Not using a pad on the bar
injury_prevention_tips: Use a pad on the bar for comfort.
Don't overextend at the top - keep a straight line from shoulders to knees.

name: Barbell Incline Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline.
Grip bar slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Lower bar to upper chest with control.
Press back up to starting position.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or safety bars.
Don't use a grip that's too wide.

name: Barbell Incline Shoulder Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on an incline bench holding a barbell overhead.
Keep arms straight.
Raise the bar by shrugging your shoulders up.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight.
Don't roll your shoulders forward at the top.

name: Barbell Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with barbell on upper back, feet together.
Step forward with one leg and lower your hips.
Keep your front knee above your ankle.
Push back up to starting position.
form_cues: Keep front knee aligned with ankle.
Step far enough to maintain balance.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight lunges.
Don't let your knee cave inward.

name: Barbell Rear Delt Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward until torso is nearly parallel to floor.
Grip barbell with wide, overhand grip.
Pull bar toward upper chest while flaring elbows out.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Start with light weight to master the movement.

name: Barbell Rollout from Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on a bench with hands on a barbell on the floor.
Keep your core tight and back flat.
Roll the bar forward, extending your body.
Pull back using your abs.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a shorter range of motion.
Stop if you feel any back pain.

name: Barbell Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a bench with back support.
Hold barbell at shoulder height, palms forward.
Press the bar straight overhead until arms are extended.
Lower back down to shoulders with control.
form_cues: Keep your back against the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or safety bars.
Keep your ribcage down to prevent arching.

name: Barbell Shrug Behind The Back
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell behind your back with pronated grip.
Keep arms straight and lift shoulders up toward ears.
Hold the contraction at the top.
Lower shoulders back down.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight.
Don't roll your shoulders forward at the top.

name: Barbell Side Split Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with barbell on upper back, feet wide apart.
Bend one knee and push hips to that side.
Lower until your other leg is straight.
Push back up to starting position.
form_cues: Bend knee in line with toes.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only.
Don't let your knee go past your toes.

name: Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bar on upper back, feet shoulder-width apart.
Push hips back and bend knees to lower down.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep knees in line with toes.
injury_prevention_tips: Use safety bars in a squat rack.
Start with bodyweight to master form.

name: Barbell Squat To A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a bench behind you.
Set bar on upper back, feet shoulder-width.
Squat down until you lightly touch the bench.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Light touch on bench, don't plop.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a sturdy bench.
Start with a higher bench and lower as you get stronger.

name: Barbell Step Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a bench or box with barbell on upper back.
Place one foot fully on the bench.
Drive through that foot to stand up on the bench.
Step back down with control and repeat.
form_cues: Step up fully, don't just tap.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only.
Make sure the bench is stable.

name: Barbell Walking Lunge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with barbell on upper back, feet together.
Step forward with one leg and lower your hips.
Drive up and bring back foot forward to lunge with other leg.
Continue walking forward with each lunge.
form_cues: Keep front knee aligned with ankle.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight lunges.
Don't let your knee cave inward.

name: Battling Ropes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing the anchored rope, feet shoulder-width apart.
Hold one end of the rope in each hand.
Alternate raising and lowering your arms rapidly.
Keep your knees slightly bent and core engaged.
common_mistakes: Using only arms instead of whole body
Not keeping tension on the rope
injury_prevention_tips: Start with shorter intervals (10-15 seconds).
Keep wrists straight.

name: Barbell Bench Press with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop chains over the barbell ends.
Lie on bench and grip bar as usual.
Lower bar to chest with control.
Press up, adding speed as chains lift off floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light chains to get used to the feel.
Use a spotter for safety.

name: Bent-Arm Barbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench with only your upper back supported.
Hold barbell over chest with slightly bent arms.
Lower weight in arc behind your head.
Bring it back up over chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Use very light weight.
Stop if you feel shoulder pain.

name: Bent-Arm Dumbbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie perpendicular on bench with shoulders on it.
Hold dumbbell with both hands over chest.
Lower weight in arc behind your head.
Bring it back up over chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a secure dumbbell with tight plates.
Start with very light weight.

name: Bent Over Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward until torso is nearly parallel to floor.
Grip barbell with pronated grip.
Pull bar to lower chest/upper stomach.
Lower back down with control.
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms instead of back
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Start with light weight to master form.

name: Bent Over Dumbbell Rear Delt Raise With Head On Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward and rest forehead on incline bench.
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging down.
Raise arms out to sides until parallel to floor.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weights.
Keep the movement controlled.

name: Bent Over Low-Pulley Side Lateral
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward until torso is nearly parallel to floor.
Hold cable handle in one hand, other hand on knee.
Raise arm out to side until parallel to floor.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Start with light weight.

name: Bent Over One-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load one end of barbell, anchor other end.
Bend forward with one hand on the loaded end.
Pull the bar up to your lower chest.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Use small plates for better range of motion.

name: Bent Over Two-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Load one end of barbell, anchor other end.
Bend forward with both hands on the loaded end.
Pull the bar up to your lower chest.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Use small plates for better range of motion.

name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward until torso is nearly parallel to floor.
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging down.
Row both dumbbells to your sides.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Start with light weight.

name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Bend forward until torso is nearly parallel to floor.
Hold dumbbells with palms facing each other.
Row both dumbbells to your sides.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep a neutral spine.
Start with light weight.

name: Bent Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean a kettlebell to one shoulder.
Lean to the opposite side while reaching down with free hand.
Press the kettlebell overhead as you lean.
Return to standing and lower back to shoulder.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the movement without weight first.
Only go as far as your mobility allows.

name: Board Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place 1-5 boards on your chest.
Lie on bench and grip bar as usual.
Lower bar to the boards with control.
Pause briefly, then press up explosively.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter.
Make sure boards are secure.

name: Body-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a forearm plank position, body in a straight line from head to heels.
Press through your forearms and palms to extend your elbows, lifting your torso up into a push-up position.
Keep your core braced and hips level throughout the movement.
Slowly lower back down to the starting forearm plank position.
form_cues: Squeeze your glutes to prevent your hips from sagging.
Keep your neck in a neutral position by looking at the floor slightly ahead of your hands.
Drive through your palms, not just your fingers.
common_mistakes: Hiking your hips up too high, turning it into an pike movement.
Leading with your head instead of your chest, which can strain the neck.
Allowing your lower back to arch excessively.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel pressure in your lower back, engage your glutes and abs harder to stabilize your pelvis.
Ensure your elbows are tracking directly behind your shoulders, not flaring out to the sides.

name: Bodyweight Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place two smooth, movable objects (like sliders or plates) under your hands in a high plank position.
Keeping your arms mostly straight, slowly slide one hand out to the side and the other in, mimicking a chest fly.
Keep your core tight and hips stable as you move.
Return to the starting plank position and repeat on the other side.
form_cues: Imagine hugging a large barrel around you.
Keep your shoulder blades pulled down and away from your ears.
Move slowly and with control to maximize chest engagement.
common_mistakes: Sagging your hips or arching your back as you move your arms.
Bending your elbows too much, turning it into a push-up.
Rushing the movement and losing tension in the chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the surface under your hands can slide smoothly to prevent jarring wrist movements.
Do not let your shoulders roll forward at the top of the movement.

name: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to the highest position with a rope attachment. Sit on a Bosu ball facing away from the machine.
Lean back so your back arches over the ball, then grab the rope handles and pull them down and in front of your head.
Crunch your ribs down towards your hips to flex your abs, lifting your shoulders off the ball.
After your crunches, sit up on the ball and perform side bends by leaning side to side.
form_cues: Focus on curling your spine, not just moving your arms.
Keep your hips stable and lifted throughout the crunch.
Exhale forcefully as you crunch to engage the deep core muscles.
common_mistakes: Pulling with your arms instead of contracting your abs.
Letting your hips sink and lose contact with the Bosu ball.
Using momentum to swing your torso up and down.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the Bosu ball is stable and placed on a non-slip surface.
Avoid hyperextending your lower back at the bottom of the crunch.

name: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a kettlebell by the handle in one hand, with the bell upside down (bottoms-up).
Hinge at your hips and lower the kettlebell slightly, keeping your arm straight.
Explosively drive your hips forward and pull the kettlebell up, keeping it close to your body.
Flip your wrist under the bell to catch it in the 'bottoms-up' position at your shoulder, elbow tucked in.
form_cues: Crush the handle as hard as you can to keep the bell stable.
Keep your elbow high and pointing forward when you catch it.
Use your hips to generate power, not just your arm.
common_mistakes: Letting the kettlebell flop over or wobble during the clean.
Shrugging your shoulder up to your ear.
Using only your bicep to pull the weight up.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a very light weight to master the wrist flip and stability.
If you cannot keep the bell stable, lower the weight to protect your elbow and shoulder.

name: Bottoms Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your legs straight and arms by your sides.
Bring your knees toward your chest while keeping your lower back pressed into the floor.
Extend your legs straight up toward the ceiling.
Lift your hips off the floor, then slowly lower back down to the start.
form_cues: Keep the movement smooth and controlled; don't swing your legs.
Exhale as you lift your hips to maximize core contraction.
Keep your chin tucked slightly to avoid straining your neck.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing your legs up instead of using your abs.
Letting your lower back arch off the floor.
Bending your knees too much during the extension.
injury_prevention_tips: If your lower back lifts off the floor, reduce the range of motion.
Place your hands under your glutes for extra support if you have sensitive lower back.

name: Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a box behind you in a squat rack. Set the bar on your upper back and step out.
Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to lower yourself down until you gently sit on the box.
Pause briefly on the box without bouncing or fully relaxing your tension.
Drive through your feet to stand back up explosively.
form_cues: Sit 'back and down' rather than 'down and forward'.
Keep your chest up and torso upright.
Push your knees out in line with your toes.
common_mistakes: Bouncing off the box, which uses momentum instead of muscle.
Sitting too far back so your shins become vertical too early (can strain knees).
Rounding your lower back when sitting on the box.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the box height allows your thighs to be at least parallel to the floor to protect the knees.
Keep your core braced tightly before you sit down to protect your spine.

name: Box Squat with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Loop resistance bands around the barbell and anchor them to the floor or rack pegs.
Set a box behind you. Step under the bar and step out.
Lower yourself under control until you gently sit on the box.
Drive up explosively against the band tension.
form_cues: Keep tension on the bands throughout the movement.
Sit back into the squat, keeping weight in your mid-foot/heels.
Keep your torso rigid to transfer force from the legs.
common_mistakes: Letting the bands pull you forward off balance.
Unlocking your hips too early before driving up.
injury_prevention_tips: Check that the bands are securely anchored so they don't snap loose.
Start with lighter bands to get used to the increasing tension at the top.

name: Box Squat with Chains
beginner_friendly_instructions: Drape chains over the barbell so they hang off the ends. Place the box behind you.
Step under the bar, step out, and lower yourself to the box.
Pause briefly on the box.
Stand up, lifting the chains off the floor as you extend.
form_cues: Keep the chains draped neatly so they don't swing wildly.
Control the descent; the weight gets lighter at the bottom.
Explode up to lift the chains.
common_mistakes: Letting the chains pile up on the floor and get tangled.
Jerking the bar to lift the chains.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the chains are not too heavy for the bar's collars to hold.
Keep your neck neutral; don't crane your neck to look at the chains.

name: Bradford/Rocky Presses
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a shoulder press station with a barbell at shoulder height.
Press the bar up just past your forehead but don't lock out your elbows.
Lower the bar down to the back of your head/upper neck.
Press it back up to the front without touching your shoulders.
form_cues: Keep your core tight to protect your lower back.
Move the bar in a vertical line; don't let it drift forward or backward.
Keep your grip stable and wrists straight.
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar onto your neck or head.
Locking out your elbows, which removes tension from the shoulders.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter weight than you would for a standard overhead press.
If you feel pinching in the shoulders, adjust the path of the bar slightly.

name: Cable Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable pulleys above shoulder height. Grab handles and step forward.
Lean forward slightly with a small bend in your elbows.
Pull your hands down and together in a wide arc until your hands meet in front of your waist.
Slowly return to the starting position.
form_cues: Imagine hugging a giant tree to activate the chest.
Keep your elbows fixed in a slightly bent position.
Focus on squeezing your pecs at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows too much, turning it into a tricep pushdown.
Using your biceps to pull instead of your chest.
Standing too upright; leaning forward helps isolate the chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the weight stack slam down; control the eccentric to protect the shoulder joint.
Ensure your feet are staggered for stability to prevent slipping.

name: Cable Deadlifts
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach straight bar handles to the lowest cable pulleys. Stand in the middle.
Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grab the handles.
Drive through your heels to stand up tall, pulling the cables with you.
Hinge back down to lower the handles, keeping your back flat.
form_cues: Keep your chest proud and shoulder blades pulled back.
Push the floor away with your feet.
Keep the cables close to your body.
common_mistakes: Pulling primarily with your arms/shoulders instead of your legs.
Letting the cables pull you forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Brace your abs as if you are about to be punched.
Ensure the cables are set to a weight that allows you to maintain perfect form.

name: Cable Incline Pushdown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on an incline bench set to a high incline. Grasp a straight bar attached to a high pulley above you.
Start with arms extended above your chest.
Pull the bar down toward your upper thighs by pulling your elbows down and back.
Return to the start slowly.
form_cues: Keep your elbows tucked in close to your sides.
Think about pulling your elbows to your pockets.
Squeeze your lats at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Flaring your elbows out to the sides.
Using momentum to swing the weight down.
Moving your shoulders forward instead of keeping them back.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not use a weight that forces you to jerk your body to move it.
Keep your head pressed firmly against the bench pad.

name: Cable Incline Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on an incline bench. Grasp a straight bar attached to a high pulley with a narrow grip.
Start with arms extended above your chest.
Bend your elbows to lower the bar behind your head, keeping elbows tucked in.
Extend your arms back up to the start.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms stationary; only your forearms should move.
Keep your elbows pointing forward, not flaring out.
Squeeze your triceps hard at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward and backward.
Using too much weight and compromising the range of motion.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure your elbows are healthy; this movement can be taxing on the tendons.
Control the weight on the way down to avoid stretching the elbow joint too aggressively.

name: Cable Iron Cross
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable pulleys to shoulder height. Stand in the middle with arms extended out to your sides like a cross.
Keeping your arms straight, pull the handles down and into your sides.
Squeeze your lats and chest at the bottom.
Slowly return your arms to the starting cross position.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows to protect the joints.
Imagine tucking your elbows into your back pockets.
Keep your chest up and shoulders down.
common_mistakes: Using your biceps to pull instead of your back/chest.
Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the movement pattern.
Avoid hyperextending your elbows at the top.

name: Cable Judo Flip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a low cable pulley. Stand sideways to the machine with a wide stance.
Grab the rope with both hands and pull it up and across your body, rotating your torso.
Imagine throwing the rope over your opposite shoulder and crunching down.
Return to the start with control.
form_cues: Rotate your torso, not just your arms.
Exhale forcefully as you 'flip' the rope.
Keep your feet planted and pivot as needed.
common_mistakes: Using only your arms to pull the rope.
Twisting your knees and hips instead of your spine.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral; avoid excessive twisting if you have back issues.
Ensure your stance is wide enough for stability.

name: Cable Lying Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie flat on a bench next to a low cable pulley. Grasp a straight bar with a narrow grip.
Start with arms extended over your chest.
Lower the bar toward your forehead by bending your elbows.
Extend your arms back up, keeping elbows tucked in.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms vertical and stationary.
Keep your elbows pointing toward the ceiling.
Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Letting your elbows flare out to the sides.
Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not lower the bar too fast; control is key for elbow health.
Ensure the bench is stable.

name: Cable One Arm Tricep Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a single handle to a high cable pulley. Stand facing the machine.
Grab the handle with one hand, tuck your elbow into your side.
Extend your arm down until it is straight.
Return to the start slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm glued to your side.
Squeeze your triceps hard at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Letting your elbow drift away from your body.
Using your shoulder to help lift the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to prevent your torso from leaning.
Use a lighter weight to ensure strict form.

name: Cable Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach an ankle strap to a low cable pulley. Lie on your back facing away from the machine.
Bend your knees and hold the strap with your ankles.
Pull your knees toward your chest, lifting your hips off the floor.
Slowly lower your hips back down.
form_cues: Initiate the movement by tilting your pelvis back.
Keep your upper body still; only your hips move.
Exhale as you lift your hips.
common_mistakes: Swinging your legs to generate momentum.
Lifting your shoulders off the floor.
Letting the weight pull your legs back too quickly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back pressed into the floor at the start.
Ensure the ankle strap is secure.

name: Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a rope to a low cable pulley. Stand facing away from the machine and grab the rope overhead.
Start with your arms extended, elbows pointing forward.
Lower the rope behind your head by bending your elbows.
Extend your arms back up to the start.
form_cues: Keep your elbows close to your head.
Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not use a weight that forces you to hyperextend your lower back.
Ensure you have enough space to move your arms freely.

name: Cable Russian Twists
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to chest height. Lie sideways on a stability ball, holding the handle with both hands.
Extend your arms straight up toward the pulley.
Rotate your torso away from the machine, keeping your hips lifted.
Return to the start and repeat.
form_cues: Keep your hips high and level.
Rotate through your thoracic spine (upper back).
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag to the floor.
Using your arms to pull instead of your core.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the stability ball is not slippery.
If you feel back pain, keep your feet closer to the ball.

name: Car Drivers
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a weight plate vertically with both hands at the 9 and 3 o'clock positions.
Stand tall with your core engaged.
Rotate the plate from side to side as if turning a steering wheel.
Keep your arms extended in front of you.
form_cues: Keep your shoulders down and relaxed.
Move only your hands and forearms; keep elbows still.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
common_mistakes: Moving your whole body or swaying.
Using too heavy a plate, causing you to jerk.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light plate to warm up the wrists and shoulders.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows.

name: Chain Handle Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach chains to two cable handles. Lie on a flat bench.
Hold the handles with the chains draped over your chest.
Extend your arms straight up, lifting the chains off your chest.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Squeeze your triceps at the top.
Control the descent so the chains don't clatter.
common_mistakes: Dropping the chains on your chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the chains are not too heavy for the handles.
Keep your wrists straight.

name: Chain Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach chains to cable handles. Lie on a flat bench holding the chains.
Start with arms extended, letting the chains hang off your chest.
Lower the chains by bending your elbows until they reach your chest.
Press back up, lifting the chains.
form_cues: Keep your elbows at a 45-degree angle to your body.
Keep your feet flat on the floor.
Press through the handles, not just the chains.
common_mistakes: Letting the chains slide off your chest uncontrollably.
Lifting your hips off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Check that the chains are securely attached.
Do not let the chains pile up on your face.

name: Chin-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with your palms facing you, hands shoulder-width apart.
Hang with arms fully extended.
Pull your chest up to the bar by driving your elbows down.
Lower yourself back down with control.
form_cues: Think about pulling your elbows into your back pockets.
Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Squeeze your back muscles at the top.
common_mistakes: Pulling with your arms/biceps only instead of your back.
Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
injury_prevention_tips: If you cannot do a full rep, use resistance bands or an assisted machine.
Warm up your shoulders thoroughly before attempting.

name: Clean and Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell at shin level with an overhand grip.
Explosively extend your hips and knees to pull the bar upward.
Drop under the bar to catch it at your shoulders (front rack position).
Stand up, then press the bar overhead. Lower it safely.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the pull.
Use your hips to generate power, not your arms.
Keep your core tight when catching the weight.
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from your body.
Not dropping low enough to catch the weight safely.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the movement with a very light weight or PVC pipe first.
Ensure you have adequate space and use bumpers if dropping the bar.

name: Clock Push-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a standard push-up position.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Push up explosively and jump your hands slightly to the '1 o'clock' position.
Perform the next rep, jumping to the '2 o'clock' position, and continue around the clock.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line during the jump.
Land softly with your elbows slightly bent.
Keep your core tight to control the landing.
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag or hike up.
Moving your feet too much (they should stay relatively planted).
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have enough floor space to move safely.
Do not attempt this if you have wrist issues.

name: Close-Grip Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench and grab the barbell with hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
Unrack the bar and lower it to your lower chest/upper abs.
Keep your elbows tucked in close to your body.
Press the bar back up to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep your elbows tucked, not flared out.
Keep your feet planted and glutes squeezed.
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out to the sides.
Bouncing the bar off your chest.
Lifting your hips off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter when going heavy.
