Keep the lifted leg as straight as possible.
common_mistakes: Bending the lifted knee too much.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel sharp pain, ease off immediately.
Use a strap or towel if you can't reach your leg.

name: Leg Extensions
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the pad to rest just above your ankles.
Align your knee with the machine's pivot point; your shin should be vertical at the start.
Press up by extending your knees, squeezing your quads at the top.
Lower the weight slowly with control, stopping just before your knees bend past 90 degrees.
form_cues: Keep your back and hips firmly planted in the seat.
Drive through your big toe to maximize quad activation.
common_mistakes: Rocking your torso back to lift heavier weight.
Letting the weight stack touch down between reps, removing tension.
Overextending the knee, causing joint strain.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not let your knees travel past your toes during the movement.
Use a full range of motion but stop if you feel sharp pain behind the kneecap.

name: Leg Lift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall next to a wall or sturdy object for balance.
Keep your standing leg slightly bent and core tight.
Lift one leg straight back behind you, leading with your heel.
Lower the leg slowly to the starting position and repeat.
form_cues: Keep your hips square to the floor; don't rotate.
Squeeze your glute at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine; avoid arching your lower back.
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward or backward.
Using momentum by swinging the leg.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement small initially to ensure control.
If you feel lower back strain, reduce the height of the lift.

name: Leg Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine with your feet flat on the platform, shoulder-width apart.
Unlock the safety handles and lower the platform until your knees are at 90 degrees.
Press the platform away by driving through your heels until your legs are extended (but not locked).
Return to the start position slowly and repeat.
form_cues: Keep your lower back pressed firmly against the pad.
Drive through your heels, not your toes.
Keep your knees in line with your feet (don't let them cave inward).
common_mistakes: Locking your knees at full extension.
Lifting your hips off the seat to get more range.
injury_prevention_tips: Never unlock the safety latches unless you are certain you can complete the rep.
Ensure your feet are placed in the center of the platform, not too high.

name: Leg Pull-In
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended and hands under your glutes for support.
Bend your knees and pull them toward your chest while lifting your hips slightly.
Pause briefly when your knees are near your chest.
Extend your legs back to the starting position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your lower back pressed into the floor.
Move from your hips, not just your knees.
Keep your feet parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing your legs.
Lifting your head and neck off the mat.
Letting your lower back arch off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the range of motion manageable to protect your lower back.
If you feel neck strain, keep your head down.

name: Leverage Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with your mid-chest.
Grip the handles and retract your shoulder blades.
Press the handles forward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and shoulder blades pulled back.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
Letting your shoulders roll forward at the start.
Bouncing the weight at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat height allows your elbows to be slightly below your shoulders.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Leverage Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand between the handles with feet hip-width apart.
Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grip the handles.
Keep your chest up and back straight as you stand up by driving through your heels.
Return the weight to the starting position slowly.
form_cues: Drive through your heels, not your toes.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Locking your knees at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core before lifting to protect your spine.
Do not let the weight drop; control the eccentric.

name: Leverage Decline Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with your lower chest.
Grip the handles and retract your shoulder blades.
Press the handles forward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and shoulder blades retracted.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Flaring your elbows out too wide.
Bouncing the weight at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is secure and comfortable.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Leverage High Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so you can reach the handles above you comfortably.
Grip the handles with palms facing down.
Pull the handles down towards your upper chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and back straight.
Pull with your back, not your arms.
Squeeze your shoulder blades at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to pull the weight down.
Shrugging your shoulders at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your spine.
Do not let the weight stack touch down between reps.

name: Leverage Incline Chest Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with your upper chest.
Grip the handles and retract your shoulder blades.
Press the handles forward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and shoulder blades retracted.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Flaring your elbows out too wide.
Bouncing the weight at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is secure and comfortable.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Leverage Iso Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with your chest.
Grip the handles with a neutral or pronated grip.
Pull the handles towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and back straight.
Pull with your back, not your arms.
Squeeze your shoulder blades at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to pull the weight.
Shrugging your shoulders at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your spine.
Do not let the weight stack touch down between reps.

name: Leverage Shoulder Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Adjust the seat so the handles align with your shoulders.
Grip the handles with palms facing forward.
Press the handles upward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly, keeping tension on the muscles.
form_cues: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your spine.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Leverage Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand between the handles with feet hip-width apart.
Grip the top handles with a comfortable grip.
Drive through your heels to stand up straight, then shrug your shoulders up towards your ears.
Lower the weight back to the starting position slowly.
form_cues: Shrug straight up and down, not forward or backward.
Squeeze your traps at the top.
common_mistakes: Bending your elbows during the shrug.
Rolling your shoulders forward or backward.
Using momentum to lift the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck in a neutral position; don't crane it up.
Avoid overloading the weight, which can lead to rounding your back.

name: London Bridges
beginner_friendly_instructions: Secure a rope to a high anchor point and stand on a stable surface below.
Grab the rope with both hands and lean back until your body is straight.
Walk your hands down the rope, lowering your body slowly.
Reverse the motion by walking your hands back up to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core and lats to control the descent.
common_mistakes: Letting your hips sag or bend.
Using only your arms instead of your back.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the anchor point is secure and can handle your body weight.
Start with a small range of motion to build strength.

name: Looking At Ceiling
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel on the floor with your knees under your hips.
Grab your heels with both hands.
Lean back and lift your hips up and forward while looking up at the ceiling.
Hold the stretch for the recommended time.
form_cues: Keep your knees in line with your hips.
Drive your hips forward to deepen the stretch.
Keep your head in line with your spine.
injury_prevention_tips: If you have lower back issues, reduce the range of motion.
Avoid if you have knee pain; use padding under knees.

name: Low Cable Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the pulleys to the lowest position and grab a handle in each hand.
Step forward to create tension, palms facing forward.
Pull the handles up and together in front of your chest.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
Squeeze your chest at the top.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing you to lean back.
Moving your upper body forward and back.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your shoulders down and away from your ears.
Control the weight on the way back to protect your shoulders.

name: Low Cable Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on a bench with a rope attachment set to a low pulley.
Grip the rope ends with palms facing each other, elbows bent at 90 degrees.
Extend your arms straight up, keeping elbows stationary.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms perpendicular to the floor.
Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
Using momentum to swing the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
Do not overextend your elbows.

name: Low Pulley Row To Neck
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a low row machine with a rope attachment.
Grip the rope with palms facing down and sit tall.
Pull the rope towards your neck, keeping your elbows high and out to the sides.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your back straight and torso stationary.
Keep your elbows high and parallel to the floor.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top.
common_mistakes: Leaning back to lift more weight.
Pulling the rope too low (towards the chest).
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck relaxed and in line with your spine.
Avoid rounding your lower back.

name: Lower Back-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor and place a foam roller under your lower back.
Cross your arms in front of you.
Lift your hips off the floor and lean back slightly.
Shift your weight slightly to one side and roll over the lower back muscles.
form_cues: Breathe deeply into the tight areas.
Avoid rolling directly over your spine.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel sharp pain, stop immediately.
Use a softer roller if you are new to SMR.

name: Lower Back Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your stomach with your arms extended by your sides.
Engage your lower back muscles to lift your chest off the ground.
Keep your head up and gaze forward.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Squeeze your glutes to protect your lower back.
Keep your neck long (don't crunch forward).
Lift your chest using your back muscles, not your arms.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel pinching, reduce the range of motion.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.

name: Lunge Pass Through
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a kettlebell in one hand.
Step forward into a lunge, lowering your back knee toward the ground.
Pass the kettlebell under your front leg to your other hand.
Drive through your front heel to return to standing and repeat on the other side.
form_cues: Keep your front knee tracking over your toes.
common_mistakes: Letting your front knee cave inward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have enough space to pass the kettlebell safely.
Keep your core tight to maintain balance.

name: Lunge Sprint
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a Smith machine at shoulder height.
Duck under the bar and rest it on your upper back.
Step one foot forward and lower into a lunge.
Explosively jump up and switch your legs in mid-air, landing in a lunge on the opposite side.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and core tight.
Drive through the heel of your front foot.
common_mistakes: Letting your front knee collapse inward.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only to master the landing mechanics.
Ensure the Smith machine safety catches are set correctly.

name: Lying Bent Leg Groin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and soles of feet together.
Have a partner hold your knees gently.
Try to squeeze your knees together while your partner resists.
Relax and let your partner gently push your knees toward the floor.
form_cues: Keep your feet close to your glutes.
Communicate with your partner about intensity.
Keep your back flat on the floor.
common_mistakes: Partner pushing too hard too fast.
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter you trust.
Never force a stretch past comfort.

name: Lying Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back in front of a low pulley with a straight bar attachment.
Grip the bar with palms facing up, arms extended.
Curl the bar up towards your chest, keeping elbows stationary.
Lower the bar slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your elbows forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure your feet are braced against the machine frame.
Use a weight that allows full control.

name: Lying Cambered Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a cambered bar under a bench and lie face down.
Grip the bar with a pronated grip wider than shoulder-width.
Row the bar up towards your chest or stomach, keeping elbows close.
Lower the bar slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your chest pressed into the bench.
Pull with your back, not your arms.
Keep your elbows close to your body.
common_mistakes: Lifting your chest off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Avoid overloading the weight, which can strain the lower back.

name: Lying Close-Grip Bar Curl On High Pulley
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a bench in front of a high pulley with a straight bar attachment.
Lie on your back with head over the end of the bench.
Grip the bar with palms up, arms extended above your shoulders.
Curl the bar down towards your chin, keeping elbows in.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms perpendicular to the floor.
Squeeze your biceps at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Moving your elbows forward or backward.
Using momentum to swing the bar.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
Do not let the bar crash down.

name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Extension Behind The Head
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding a barbell with a shoulder-width grip.
Extend your arms straight up over your chest.
Lower the bar behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms stationary.
Extend your arms back up to the start position.
form_cues: Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not lower the bar too far behind your head if you have shoulder issues.
Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.

name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Press To Chin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding a barbell with a shoulder-width grip.
Extend your arms straight up over your chest.
Lower the bar towards your chin by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms stationary.
Extend your arms back up to the start position.
form_cues: Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not lower the bar too close to your face if you have shoulder issues.
Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.

name: Lying Crossover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs extended.
Cross one leg over your body with the knee bent.
Have a partner hold your shoulder and the crossed leg.
Try to lift your bent knee off the ground while your partner resists, then relax and let them push it toward the floor.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter you trust.
Never force a stretch past comfort.

name: Lying Dumbbell Tricep Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding two dumbbells above your chest.
Lower the dumbbells towards your ears by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms stationary.
Extend your arms back up to the start position.
Keep your elbows tucked in throughout.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms perpendicular to the floor.
Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not lower the dumbbells too far if you have shoulder issues.
Keep your core engaged.

name: Lying Face Down Plate Neck Resistance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a bench with your head off the end.
Hold a weight plate behind your head.
Lower your head down (looking at the floor), then lift it back up against the resistance.
Keep your neck movements slow and controlled.
form_cues: Keep your neck in line with your spine.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight or no weight.
Stop if you feel any pinching or sharp pain.

name: Lying Face Up Plate Neck Resistance
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on a bench with your head off the end.
Hold a weight plate on your forehead.
Lower your head back (looking at the floor), then lift it back up against the resistance.
Keep your neck movements slow and controlled.
form_cues: Keep your neck in line with your spine.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight or no weight.
Stop if you feel any pinching or sharp pain.

name: Lying Glute
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent.
Cross one ankle over the opposite knee.
Grab behind the supporting thigh and pull it towards your chest.
Hold the stretch.
form_cues: Keep your head and shoulders on the floor.
Feel the stretch in the glute of the crossed leg.
common_mistakes: Lifting your head off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: If you have knee issues, be careful with the crossed leg position.
Pull gently to avoid strain.

name: Lying Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs extended.
Have a partner lift one leg straight up towards the ceiling.
Try to flex your knee against your partner's resistance.
Relax and let your partner gently push the leg closer to your head.
form_cues: Keep your hips on the floor.
Keep your leg straight (slight bend is okay).
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter you trust.
Never force a stretch past comfort.

name: Lying High Bench Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a high bench with your chest over the edge.
Hold a barbell with a supinated grip (palms up), arms extended down.
Curl the bar up towards your chest, keeping elbows stationary.
Lower the bar slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your elbows forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
Use a weight that allows full control.

name: Lying Leg Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the leg curl machine with the pad just above your ankles.
Grab the handles and keep your hips pressed into the pad.
Curl your legs up towards your glutes, squeezing your hamstrings.
Lower the weight slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your hips pressed into the pad.
Squeeze your hamstrings at the top.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the pad.
Using momentum to swing the weight.
Letting the weight stack touch down between reps.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the pad is adjusted correctly.
Do not hyperextend your lower back.

name: Lying Machine Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on the machine with your knees bent and feet on the platform.
Position your shoulders under the pads.
Press through your feet to extend your hips and knees until your body is straight.
Lower the weight slowly back to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your back flat against the pad.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Locking your knees at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the machine is set to a comfortable height.
Do not let your knees travel past your toes.

name: Lying One-Arm Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand.
Let the dumbbell hang straight down, palm facing your body.
Raise the dumbbell out to the side until your arm is parallel to the floor.
Lower the dumbbell slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your chest pressed into the bench.
Keep a slight bend in your elbow.
Lead with your elbow, not your hand.
common_mistakes: Lifting your chest off the bench.
Using momentum to swing the weight.
Rotating your wrist during the lift.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight to master the form.
Avoid jerking the weight up.

name: Lying Prone Quadriceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor.
Bend one knee and bring your heel towards your glute.
Have a partner hold your ankle and knee.
Try to extend your knee against your partner's resistance, then relax and let them push your heel closer to your glute.
form_cues: Keep your hips on the floor.
Feel the stretch in the front of your thigh.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter you trust.
Never force a stretch past comfort.

name: Lying Rear Delt Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand.
Let the dumbbells hang straight down, palms facing your body.
Raise the dumbbells out to the side until your arms are parallel to the floor.
Lower the dumbbells slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your chest pressed into the bench.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
Lead with your elbows, not your hands.
common_mistakes: Lifting your chest off the bench.
Using momentum to swing the weights.
Rotating your wrists during the lift.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weights to master the form.
Avoid jerking the weights up.

name: Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face up on a bench with dumbbells in each hand, arms extended down by your sides.
Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, rotating your wrists so palms face up.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
Lower the dumbbells slowly back to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your elbows pinned to your sides.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your elbows forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
Use a weight that allows full control.

name: Lying T-Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the T-bar machine pad.
Grip the handles with a neutral or pronated grip.
Pull the handles towards your chest, squeezing your back muscles.
Lower the weight slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your chest pressed into the pad.
Pull with your back, not your arms.
Keep your elbows close to your body.
common_mistakes: Lifting your chest off the pad.
Using momentum to pull the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Avoid overloading the weight, which can strain the lower back.

name: Lying Triceps Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with an EZ bar on the floor behind your head.
Grip the bar with a medium overhand grip and lift it above your chest.
Lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms stationary.
Extend your arms back up to the start position.
form_cues: Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Moving your upper arms forward or backward.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not lower the bar too far if you have shoulder issues.
Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.

name: Machine Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the seat so the handles align with your mid-chest.
Grip the handles and retract your shoulder blades.
Press the handles forward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad.
Keep your chest up and shoulder blades retracted.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Letting the weight stack touch down between reps.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is adjusted correctly.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Machine Bicep Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the seat so the handles align with your biceps.
Place your upper arms against the pads and grip the handles.
Curl the handles up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps.
Lower the weight slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Moving your elbows forward or backward.
Letting the weight stack touch down between reps.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is adjusted correctly.
Do not overextend your elbows.

name: Machine Preacher Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the seat so the pad aligns with your armpits.
Place your upper arms on the pad and grip the handles with palms up.
Curl the handles up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps.
Lower the weight slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms stationary on the pad.
Squeeze your biceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arms off the pad.
Using momentum to lift the weight.
Letting the weight stack touch down between reps.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is adjusted correctly.
Do not overextend your elbows.

name: Machine Shoulder (Military) Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the seat so the handles align with your shoulders.
Grip the handles with palms facing forward.
Press the handles upward until your arms are extended.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your back pressed firmly against the pad.
Don't lock your elbows at full extension.
common_mistakes: Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core engaged to protect your spine.
Avoid overextending your elbows.

name: Machine Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the machine and adjust the seat so the handles align with your triceps.
Place your upper arms against the pads and grip the handles.
Extend your arms by straightening your elbows, squeezing your triceps.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Squeeze your triceps at the top.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Moving your elbows forward or backward.
Letting the weight stack touch down between reps.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the seat is adjusted correctly.
Do not overextend your elbows.

name: Middle Back Shrug
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on an incline bench with dumbbells in each hand.
Let your arms hang straight down, palms facing each other.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together without bending your arms.
Return to the start position slowly.
form_cues: Keep your chest pressed into the bench.
Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together.
common_mistakes: Lifting your chest off the bench.
Using momentum to swing the weights.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weights to master the form.
Avoid shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.

name: Middle Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and hands on hips.
Twist your torso to one side until you feel a stretch.
Hold for 10-15 seconds.
Repeat on the other side.
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly and controlled.
Do not force the stretch if you feel pain.

name: Mixed Grip Chin
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand facing you and the other facing away.
Hang with arms extended.
Pull yourself up until your chin is over the bar.
Lower yourself slowly to the start position.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and core tight.
Pull with your back, not just your arms.
Keep your shoulders down and away from your ears.
common_mistakes: Shrugging your shoulders up to your ears.
Not going through a full range of motion.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bar is secure.
If you cannot do a full rep, use a resistance band or assisted machine.

name: Monster Walk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a resistance band around both ankles and another around both knees.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart to create initial tension in the bands.
Take small, controlled steps forward, leading with one foot and following with the other.
Walk backward to the starting position while maintaining tension.
form_cues: Maintain a slight bend in the knees (athletic stance).
Step out just enough to feel constant tension on the bands.
common_mistakes: Taking steps that are too wide, causing the bands to snap.
Standing too upright; slight forward lean is better for glute activation.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bands are not frayed or damaged before use.
Keep your core engaged to prevent excessive lower back arching.

name: Muscle Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grip the rings or bar with a false grip (wrist over the object).
Pull explosively, driving your elbows down and back.
As you reach the top, push your chest through and press your body up.
Lower yourself down with control to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep the rings close to your body during the transition.
Think 'pull' then 'push'don't try to press immediately.
Hollow your body slightly to maintain momentum.
common_mistakes: Letting the rings drift away from the body, losing leverage.
injury_prevention_tips: Master strict pull-ups and dips before attempting muscle ups.
Use resistance bands for assistance if you are new to the movement.

name: Narrow Stance Hack Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Position yourself in the hack squat machine with shoulders under pads.
Place feet close together (less than shoulder-width) and toes slightly out.
Unrack the weight and lower until thighs are below parallel.
Drive through your heels to return to the start.
form_cues: Keep your head pressed firmly against the pad.
Ensure knees track over your toes.
Keep your lower back flat against the pad.
common_mistakes: Lifting your heels off the platform.
Rounding your lower back at the bottom of the squat.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the range of motion.
Never fully lock out your knees at the top.

name: Narrow Stance Leg Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the leg press machine and place feet close together on the platform.
Unrack the safety stops by straightening your legs.
Lower the weight until your knees form a 90-degree angle.
Press back up, driving through your heels.
form_cues: Keep your lower back glued to the pad.
Don't lock your knees at the top.
common_mistakes: Lifting the hips off the seat to get more range.
injury_prevention_tips: Always engage your core to protect the spine.
Ensure safety pins are re-engaged after finishing the set.

name: Narrow Stance Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set the barbell on a rack at chest height.
Step under the bar, place it on your upper back, and unrack.
Step back and place feet 3-6 inches apart, toes slightly out.
Squat down until thighs are below parallel, then drive up.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and eyes forward.
Push your knees out to prevent them from caving in.
common_mistakes: Rising onto the toes at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a squat rack with safety bars.
Warm up hips and ankles to improve depth safely.

name: Natural Glute Ham Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor your feet under a heavy object or machine pad.
Start in a kneeling position with torso upright.
Slowly lower your torso toward the floor, resisting with your hamstrings.
Use your hands to catch yourself, then push back up to start.
form_cues: Keep a straight line from head to knees.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Hyperextending the lower back at the top.
Falling too fast without muscular control.
injury_prevention_tips: Pad your knees with a mat.
Use a band for assistance if you cannot control the descent.

name: Neck-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit or stand holding a foam roller or massage ball.
Place the roller against the side of your neck (not the spine).
Gently tilt your head to apply pressure to tight spots.
Hold on tender spots for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Breathe deeply to relax the muscles.
Avoid rolling directly over the bony spine.
common_mistakes: Applying pressure directly to the cervical spine.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a soft roller to start; avoid hard lacrosse balls on the neck.
Stop immediately if you feel nerve tingling or numbness.

name: Neck Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with a barbell.
Grip the bar with a medium width and lower it to your upper chest/neck.
Press the bar straight up until arms are locked.
Lower with control back to the neck.
form_cues: Keep your feet planted firmly on the floor.
Keep your chin tucked slightly to protect the airway.
common_mistakes: Bouncing the bar off the neck/throat.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a padded bar or towel for comfort.
Start with very light weight to master the path.

name: Oblique Crunches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Place one hand behind your head and the other by your side.
Lift your shoulder and rotate your torso to bring your elbow toward the opposite knee.
Lower back down with control.
form_cues: Lead with your elbow, not your shoulder.
Keep your lower back pressed into the floor.
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your hand.
Using momentum instead of muscle contraction.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the range of motion manageable to avoid hip strain.
If you have neck pain, place your hand on your thigh instead.

name: Oblique Crunches - On The Floor
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with legs stacked and knees slightly bent.
Place your top hand behind your head.
Lift your torso by contracting your side abs, bringing your elbow toward your hip.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep hips stacked; don't roll backward.
Focus on lifting with your side muscles, not your neck.
Keep the movement short and controlled.
common_mistakes: Twisting the torso too far, turning it into a rotation exercise.
Letting the top hip drift forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the neck neutral; do not strain it.
Place a mat under your hip for comfort.

name: On-Your-Back Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back on a bench or step.
Hang one leg off the side and grab your foot.
Pull your heel toward your glute.
Hold the stretch, then switch sides.
common_mistakes: Arching the lower back to get more stretch.
Pulling the foot too far laterally.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure your grip is on the top of the foot, not the toes.
Do not force the stretch if you feel knee pain.

name: On Your Side Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with bottom knee bent for stability.
Grab your top foot and pull it toward your glute.
Push your hip forward slightly to intensify.
Hold, then switch sides.
common_mistakes: Letting the top leg drift behind the body.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a yoga strap if you can't reach your foot.
Avoid if you have hip impingement pain.

name: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place one knee and hand on a flat bench.
Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand with arm extended.
Pull the dumbbell up toward your hip, keeping elbow close.
Lower the weight slowly.
form_cues: Keep your back flat (parallel to floor).
Pull with your elbow, not your wrist.
Squeeze your shoulder blade at the top.
common_mistakes: Rotating the torso to swing the weight up.
Jerking the weight instead of pulling smoothly.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral (don't look up).
Ensure your supporting leg is stable.

name: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Press the weight up with a slight elbow bend.
Lower the weight out to the side in a wide arc.
Bring the weight back up, squeezing the chest.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow (don't lock out).
common_mistakes: Lowering the weight too low (shoulder impingement risk).
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter weight than you think you need.
Stop if you feel pain in the front of the shoulder.

name: One-Arm High-Pulley Cable Side Bends
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable pulley to the highest position.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle.
Keep your arm locked at your side.
Bend laterally toward the opposite side, then return to center.
form_cues: Keep hips forward (don't push hips back).
Keep the cable arm pinned to your side.
common_mistakes: Pulling with the arm instead of the obliques.
Rocking your hips back and forth.
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weight to avoid spinal compression.
Keep the movement controlled to protect the lower back.

name: One-Arm Incline Lateral Raise
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on an incline bench.
Hold a dumbbell in your top hand, arm extended down.
Raise the dumbbell up toward the ceiling.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your arm parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is secure.
Avoid if you have existing shoulder impingement.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the kettlebell between your feet.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Explosively extend hips and knees to pull the bell up.
Flip the bell so it rests on your forearm at shoulder height.
form_cues: Keep the bell close to your body.
Punch your hand through at the top.
Absorb the weight with your legs, not your lower back.
common_mistakes: Letting the bell swing out away from the body.
Catching the weight with a stiff arm.
injury_prevention_tips: Practice the movement without weight first.
Keep your wrist straight to avoid strain.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean and Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip your knees slightly.
Drive through your legs and press the bell overhead.
Lock out your arm and return the bell to the shoulder.
form_cues: Use leg drive to assist the press.
common_mistakes: Pressing with only the shoulder (no leg drive).
Leaning back too far during the press.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the clean and strict press separately first.
Ensure you have enough space overhead.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor with a kettlebell in one hand.
Pull the bell to your chest while keeping elbow tucked.
Press the bell straight up until arm is locked.
Lower back to chest.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm touching the floor.
common_mistakes: Letting the elbow flare out too wide.
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to protect the shoulder joint.
Keep the non-working hand on the floor for stability.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip down quickly by bending knees.
Drive up explosively and lock out the arm overhead.
Return to the start.
form_cues: Punch the floor with your legs.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or learn the bail-out technique.
Ensure the floor is not slippery.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the bell straight up and slightly out to the side.
Lock out overhead.
Lower back to shoulder with control.
form_cues: Keep your lat engaged (pack the shoulder).
Keep your eyes on the bell.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light until form is perfect.
Avoid if you feel clicking in the shoulder.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the bell straight up overhead.
Lock out the arm.
Lower back to shoulder.
form_cues: Keep elbow tucked slightly in front of the body.
common_mistakes: Flaring the elbow out to the side.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the shoulder is warmed up.
Don't let the bell drift behind your head.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Push Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip slightly by bending your knees.
Drive up explosively to help push the weight overhead.
Lock out and lower back down.
form_cues: Use leg drive to initiate the press.
Keep the elbow slightly in front of the bar.
common_mistakes: Not using the leg drive effectively.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your back straight; don't hyperextend.
Ensure you have good knee stability.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the kettlebell slightly in front of you.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Pull the bell toward your hip.
Lower back down with control.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral.
Ensure your grip is secure.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the bell between your feet.
Hinge and pull the bell up explosively.
As it reaches chest height, punch your hand straight up.
Lock out overhead and absorb the weight.
form_cues: Keep the bell close to your body.
common_mistakes: Letting the bell flip over the top of the hand.
Catching the weight with a bent wrist.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the clean before attempting the snatch.
Use a chalk to prevent slipping.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder.
Dip and drive up explosively.
Split your legs (one forward, one back) to catch the weight overhead.
Bring feet together and lower the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have enough room for the split.
Practice the split footwork without weight first.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start with the bell between your feet.
Explosively pull the bell up.
As you reach the top, split your legs to catch the bell overhead.
Stand up and bring feet together.
form_cues: Land stable in the lunge position.
common_mistakes: Catching the weight with a soft arm.
Landing with the feet too close together.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the standard snatch first.
Check your footing surface is not slippery.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Swings
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell slightly in front of you.
Hinge at the hips and grab the handle.
Hike the bell back between your legs.
Snap your hips forward to swing the bell to chest height.
form_cues: This is a hip hinge, not a squat.
Squeeze your glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Squatting the weight up instead of hinging.
Using your arms to lift the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't swing too high (shoulder height is max).
Keep your spine neutral.

name: One-Arm Long Bar Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a barbell in a landmine or corner.
Stand sideways to the bar and grab the end with one hand.
Hinge slightly at the hips and keep chest up.
Pull the bar toward your hip.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bar is secure in the corner.
Keep your neck neutral.

name: One-Arm Medicine Ball Slam
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand in a staggered stance holding a medicine ball in one hand.
Raise the ball overhead, extending your body.
Slam the ball down forcefully between your feet.
Catch the bounce and repeat.
form_cues: Use your whole body to generate force.
Keep your arm straight during the slam.
common_mistakes: Bending too much at the waist.
Slamming the ball too far forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the floor can handle the impact.
Keep your back straight; don't round your spine.

name: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell between your feet.
Pull the bell up explosively.
Let the bell flip so the ball rests in your open palm.
Catch it and lower back down.
common_mistakes: Catching the bell with a bent wrist.
Letting the bell fly too far out.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight.
Use chalk for a better grip.

name: One-Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Clean and press the kettlebell overhead with one arm.
Keep the bell locked out overhead.
Squat down until thighs are parallel to the floor.
Stand back up while keeping the bell stable.
common_mistakes: Leaning too far to one side.
injury_prevention_tips: Master the overhead press and goblet squat separately first.
Ensure you have full shoulder mobility.

name: One-Arm Side Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand next to a barbell on the floor.
Grab the bar with one hand (suitcase style).
Keep your back straight and chest up.
Stand up by driving through your legs.
form_cues: Squeeze the glutes at the top.
common_mistakes: Leaning the torso to the side.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master stability.
Keep your core braced tightly.

name: One-Arm Side Laterals
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Lean slightly to the side of the weight.
Raise the dumbbell out to the side until arm is parallel to the floor.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a light weight to protect the rotator cuff.
Don't go too high (stop at shoulder height).

name: One-Legged Cable Kickback
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach an ankle cuff to a low cable.
Face away from the machine and secure the cuff.
Keep your torso still and kick your leg straight back.
Return to the start with control.
form_cues: Squeeze your glute at the top.
Keep your standing leg slightly bent.
Keep your hips square to the front.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to avoid jerking.
Ensure the ankle cuff is secure.

name: One Arm Against Wall
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing a wall.
Place one forearm flat against the wall.
Lean your body away from the wall.
Hold the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't force the stretch.
Avoid if you have shoulder pain.

name: One Arm Chin-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand (palm facing you).
Use a towel or other hand for assistance if needed.
Pull your chest up to the bar.
Lower yourself down slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a resistance band for assistance.
Master regular chin-ups first.

name: One Arm Dumbbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell in one hand.
Press the weight up until your arm is locked.
Lower the weight slowly to your chest.
Press back up.
common_mistakes: Lifting your hips off the bench.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to learn the balance.
Use your non-working hand to help rack the weight.

name: One Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench and hold a dumbbell in one hand.
Place your upper arm on the pad.
Curl the weight up until your bicep is fully contracted.
Lower the weight slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm glued to the pad.
common_mistakes: Lifting your upper arm off the pad.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow at the bottom.
Use a lighter weight to avoid tendon strain.

name: One Arm Floor Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on the floor holding a barbell or dumbbell in one hand.
Lower the weight until your upper arm touches the floor.
Press the weight back up to lockout.
Repeat.
form_cues: Keep your upper arm resting on the floor.
common_mistakes: Bouncing the weight off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a spotter or safety arms if using a heavy barbell.
Keep your non-working hand on the floor for stability.

name: One Arm Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a lat pulldown machine and adjust the knee pad.
Grab the handle with one hand.
Pull the handle down to your chest.
Return the handle up slowly.
form_cues: Drive your elbow down and back.
common_mistakes: Pulling with your bicep instead of your back.
Using momentum by leaning back too far.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't let the weight stack slam up.
Keep your shoulder down before pulling.

name: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell with a palm-down grip.
Extend your arm straight up.
Lower the weight behind your head by bending your elbow.
Extend back up.
form_cues: Squeeze the tricep at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow.
Use a lighter weight to protect the joint.

name: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell with a palm-up grip.
Extend your arm straight up.
Lower the weight behind your head.
Extend back up.
injury_prevention_tips: Control the weight carefully.
Stop if you feel elbow pain.

name: One Half Locust
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on the floor.
Bend one knee and grab your foot with your hand.
Lift your chest and your foot simultaneously.
Lower back down and switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your hips pressed into the floor.
common_mistakes: Letting the knee drop to the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Be gentle with your lower back.
Skip this if you have lower back pain.

name: One Handed Hang
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with one hand.
Keep your feet on the floor or a step.
Let your body hang, putting weight on the arm.
Hold for time, then switch sides.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't jump off the bar; step down gently.
Use a towel if the bar is thin and hurts your hand.

name: One Knee To Chest
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back.
Pull one knee toward your chest.
Hold the back of your thigh (not the knee).
Hold the stretch, then switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your lower back on the floor.
common_mistakes: Pulling on the shin (bad for knee).
Lifting your hips off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the stretch gentle.
Avoid if you have acute lower back pain.

name: One Leg Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell across your upper back.
Place one foot on a bench behind you.
Squat down with your front leg until parallel.
Drive back up through the front heel.
form_cues: Keep your front knee tracking over your toes.
Keep your back foot lightly on the bench.
common_mistakes: Letting the front knee cave inward.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with bodyweight only.
Ensure your knee is stable before adding weight.

name: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place the bell between your feet.
Pull the bell up explosively.
Flip the bell so the ball lands in your open palm.
Catch it and lower down.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light.
Use chalk.

name: Otis-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back holding a weight to your chest.
Perform a sit-up.
As you reach the top, press the weight overhead.
Lower the weight to your chest and reverse the sit-up.
form_cues: Keep the weight close to your body on the way up.
Press straight up at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Start without weight to master the movement.
Don't flatten your lower back completely at the bottom.

name: Overhead Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set cable pulleys higher than your head.
Stand in the middle and grab handles with palms up.
Curl your hands down toward your shoulders.
Return to the start slowly.
form_cues: Keep your upper arms parallel to the floor.
Squeeze the biceps at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Moving the elbows forward or back.
Using body English to move the weight.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight.
Don't lock out your elbows at the top.

name: Overhead Lat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright with a partner behind you.
Raise one arm straight up, then bend your elbow to touch your back.
Keep your arm in that position while your partner holds your wrist and tricep.
Try to pull your upper arm down, but your partner resists for 10-20 seconds. Then relax and let them gently push your arm further for another 10-20 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your torso upright and don't lean back.
Only your upper arm should move during the resistance phase.
Communicate with your partner to ensure pressure is firm but not painful.
common_mistakes: Allowing the partner to push too hard, causing pain.
Moving the torso instead of isolating the lat.
Not relaxing after the isometric hold to maximize the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a slow, controlled motion during the passive stretch.
Avoid forcing the joint past its comfortable range of motion.

name: Overhead Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Interlace your fingers and turn your palms up toward the ceiling.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Reach upward while gently pulling your tailbone down to lengthen your spine.
form_cues: Engage your glutes to protect your lower back.
Keep your arms straight but not locked out.
common_mistakes: Shrugging shoulders up to the ears.
injury_prevention_tips: If you have shoulder impingement, limit the range of motion slightly.
Move slowly; avoid bouncing.

name: Overhead Triceps
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit upright with a partner behind you.
Raise one arm straight up, then bend your elbow to touch your back.
Keep your arm in that position while your partner holds your wrist and elbow.
Try to extend your arm up, but your partner resists for 10-20 seconds. Then relax and let them gently pull your wrist down for another 10-20 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your elbow pointing toward the ceiling.
common_mistakes: Shrugging the shoulder during the stretch.
injury_prevention_tips: Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain in the elbow joint.
Ensure the partner supports the arm, don't let it hang loose.

name: Pallof Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable machine to shoulder height.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with both hands.
Step away until there is tension, feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Press the handle straight out in front of your chest, hold for 2-3 seconds, and return slowly.
form_cues: Brace your core like you're about to be punched.
Keep hips square to the front; don't let them rotate.
common_mistakes: Letting the cable pull your torso sideways.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light weight to master the anti-rotation aspect.
Wear flat-soled shoes for stability.

name: Pallof Press With Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a cable machine to shoulder height.
Stand sideways to the machine and grab the handle with one hand.
Step away, then bring your other hand to the handle.
Press out, then rotate your torso away from the machine until your arms are perpendicular to the cable. Return to center.
form_cues: Control the rotation; don't let momentum swing you.
common_mistakes: Letting the hips rotate faster than the shoulders (disconnection).
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your spine neutral; avoid twisting into excessive extension.
Use a lighter weight than standard Pallof Press.

name: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with two dumbbells on it.
Rest your forearms on the bench with your wrists hanging off the edge, palms facing down.
Curl your wrists up toward your body.
Lower the weights slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Only move the wrists; forearms stay planted.
Keep elbows tucked into your sides.
Squeeze at the top of the movement.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing sloppy form.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to avoid tendon strain.
Ensure your wrists don't hyperextend at the bottom.

name: Palms-Down Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with a barbell.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing down.
Curl the bar up by flexing your wrists.
Lower the bar slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Keep forearms flush against the bench.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up.
Gripping too tightly, causing forearm cramps.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter bar or dumbbells if you feel wrist pain.
Don't let the bar roll out of your fingers.

name: Palms-Up Barbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with a barbell.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing up.
Curl the bar up by flexing your wrists toward your forearms.
Lower the bar slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Keep wrists neutral at the bottom (don't hyperextend).
common_mistakes: Using weight that is too heavy.
injury_prevention_tips: Stop if you feel pain in the wrist joint.
Ensure the bench supports the forearm fully.

name: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
beginner_friendly_instructions: Kneel next to a bench with two dumbbells.
Rest your forearms on the bench with wrists hanging off, palms facing up.
Curl the dumbbells up by flexing your wrists.
Lower them slowly to stretch the forearms.
form_cues: Squeeze the forearms at the top.
common_mistakes: Rotating the wrists during the movement.
Letting dumbbells roll out of hands.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a controlled tempo to protect tendons.
Ensure wrists don't hyperextend at the bottom.

name: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
Lift your tailbone slightly off the floor (posterior pelvic tilt).
Engage your abs and glutes.
Lift your entire spine off the floor until you form a bridge, then lower slowly.
form_cues: Drive through your heels to lift.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement slow and controlled to protect the lumbar spine.
Avoid if you have acute lower back pain.

name: Peroneals-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side with a foam roller under the outside of your lower leg.
Support your weight with your forearm and top leg.
Roll from just below the knee to above the ankle.
Pause on tender spots for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your core engaged to avoid tipping over.
Point your toes slightly down to target the peroneals.
common_mistakes: Putting too much weight on the roller (causing pain).
Rolling directly over the ankle bone.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid the bony parts of the ankle.
Do not force the muscle if it feels bruised.

name: Peroneals Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with one leg extended.
Loop a band or towel around the foot.
Pull the foot inward (inversion) so the sole faces your other leg.
Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your knee straight but not locked.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up the ankles before stretching.
Stop if you feel sharp pain.

name: Physioball Hip Bridge
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the ball, then roll down until your upper back is resting on it.
Place feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart.
Drive through your heels to lift your hips toward the ceiling.
Lower hips back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your chin tucked (don't look at the ceiling).
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the ball is properly inflated so it doesn't slip.
Keep feet wide enough for stability.

name: Pin Presses
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set pins in a power rack just below your chest or at sticking point.
Lie on the bench and set up tight (shoulders retracted).
Unrack the bar from the pins.
Lower the bar to the pins, pause, then explode up.
form_cues: Keep your shoulder blades squeezed together.
Drive your feet into the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure pins are set securely.
Don't use this variation if you have shoulder impingement.

name: Piriformis-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on a foam roller with one ankle crossed over the opposite knee.
Shift your weight onto the glute of the crossed leg.
Roll over the glute area until you find a tender spot.
Hold the spot for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Breathe deeply to relax the muscle.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid the lower back; focus on the glute.
Do not force the stretch if it causes sciatic nerve pain.

name: Plank
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a pushup position but rest on your forearms.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core and glutes.
Hold the position without letting your hips sag.
form_cues: Keep your elbows directly under your shoulders.
Look at the floor slightly ahead of your hands.
injury_prevention_tips: If your lower back hurts, drop to your knees.
Ensure wrists are neutral if doing high plank.

name: Plate Pinch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Take two smooth-sided weight plates.
Press them together with the smooth sides facing out.
Pinch the plates between your fingers and thumb.
Lift them off the ground and hold for time.
form_cues: Keep your arm by your side.
common_mistakes: Using plates with ridges (harder to pinch).
Dropping the plates on your feet.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with lighter plates (e.g., 5-10 lbs).
Don't let the plates slip; if they do, let them fall safely.

name: Plate Twist
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet hovering slightly off the ground.
Hold a weight plate with both hands in front of your chest.
Twist your torso to one side, touching the plate to the floor.
Twist to the other side and repeat.
form_cues: Move through the torso, not just the arms.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the plate.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to moderate.
Move slowly to protect the spine.

name: Platform Hamstring Slides
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs straight.
Place a towel or slider under one heel.
Slide the heel toward your butt by bending the knee.
Slide back out to straighten the leg.
form_cues: Keep your hips on the floor.
Control the movement; don't let the leg snap back.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the surface is smooth to avoid catching.
Stop if you feel hamstring cramping.

name: Plie Dumbbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold one dumbbell vertically against your chest.
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed out.
Squat down by bending knees and pushing hips back.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and proud.
Knees track in line with toes.
common_mistakes: Rising onto toes at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Start without weight to master the stance.
Ensure your feet are turned out comfortably.

name: Plyo Kettlebell Pushups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor.
Get into a pushup position with one hand on the bell and one on the floor.
Perform a pushup, then explosively push up to switch hands to the other side of the bell.
Repeat the switch with each rep.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line.
common_mistakes: Landing with a stiff arm (wrist injury risk).
Not getting enough height to clear the bell.
injury_prevention_tips: Master standard pushups first.
Ensure the kettlebell is stable and won't tip.

name: Posterior Tibialis Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with one leg extended.
Loop a band or towel around the foot.
Pull the foot outward (eversion) so the outside of the foot moves toward you.
Hold for 20-30 seconds.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up the ankle first.
Stop if you feel pain on the inside of the ankle.

name: Power Clean
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, bar over mid-foot.
Hinge at hips and grip the bar, keeping back flat.
Explosively extend hips and knees, then shrug and pull the bar up.
Drop under the bar and catch it on your shoulders with a slight squat.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
Triple extension (ankles, knees, hips) is key.
Keep your chest up during the pull.
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from the body.
Rounding the back off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Learn the movement with a PVC pipe or empty bar first.
Use weightlifting shoes or flat, hard-soled shoes.

name: Power Partials
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides.
Lift the weights out to the side only up to shoulder height.
Pause briefly at the top.
Lower them back down with control.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in elbows.
Lead with your pinky finger slightly higher than the thumb.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to avoid shoulder impingement.
Don't go higher than shoulder height.

name: Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench with an EZ-bar.
Grip the bar and rest your upper arms on the pad.
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders.
Lower it slowly until arms are nearly straight.
form_cues: Keep your armpits glued to the bench.
Squeeze the biceps at the top.
Control the weight on the way down.
common_mistakes: Lifting your elbows off the pad.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend the elbow at the bottom.
Use a weight that allows full control.

name: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench holding dumbbells.
Rest upper arms on the pad with palms facing each other.
Curl the dumbbells up simultaneously.
Lower them slowly.
common_mistakes: Rotating wrists (turning into a regular curl).
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure dumbbells are secure in your grip.
Stop if you feel wrist strain.

name: Press Sit-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench with feet secured.
Hold a light barbell or plate on your chest.
Sit up while pressing the weight overhead.
Lower the weight as you lie back down.
common_mistakes: Letting the weight pull you forward.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with very light weight or no weight.
Avoid if you have lower back issues.

name: Prone Manual Hamstring
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a bench or floor.
Have a partner hold your ankles.
Curl your legs up against your partner's resistance.
Lower slowly against resistance.
form_cues: Keep hips pressed into the bench.
Communicate with partner for appropriate resistance.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with light resistance.
Ensure your partner knows how to spot safely.

name: Pull Through
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand facing away from a low cable machine with a rope attachment.
Reach between your legs and grab the rope.
Hinge at the hips and let the weight pull you forward.
Drive your hips forward to stand up straight.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in your knees.
common_mistakes: Using arms to pull instead of hips.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the weight light to master the hinge.
Don't let the weight pull you into a rounded back.

name: Pullups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab the bar with an overhand grip, hands wider than shoulders.
Hang with arms fully extended.
Pull your chest toward the bar by driving elbows down.
Lower yourself slowly to the start.
form_cues: Start the movement by depressing your shoulder blades.
common_mistakes: Not going through full range of motion.
injury_prevention_tips: If you can't do a pullup, use bands or an assisted machine.
Avoid jerking your neck.

name: Push-Up Wide
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a plank position with hands wider than shoulders.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Keep your elbows tucked slightly.
Push back up to the start.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line.
Squeeze your chest at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: If wrists hurt, use pushup handles.
Don't go too low if you have shoulder issues.

name: Push-Ups - Close Triceps Position
beginner_friendly_instructions: Get into a plank position with hands close together (under chest).
Lower your chest to your hands.
Keep elbows tucked close to your sides.
Push back up explosively.
form_cues: Keep your elbows tracking back, not flaring.
Hands should form a diamond shape.
injury_prevention_tips: Modify on knees if needed.
Keep wrists neutral.

name: Push-Ups With Feet Elevated
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your feet on a bench or box.
Get into a plank position with hands on the floor.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Push back up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the bench is stable.
Don't elevate too high initially.

name: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your shins or feet on a stability ball.
Get into a plank position with hands on the floor.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Push back up while stabilizing on the ball.
form_cues: Don't let the ball roll side to side.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with shins on the ball before progressing to feet.
Clear the area around you.

name: Push Up to Side Plank
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a pushup position.
Perform a pushup.
As you come up, shift weight to one hand and rotate into a side plank, reaching the other hand to the ceiling.
Return to pushup position, do another pushup, and switch sides.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line during the side plank.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral.
Modify on knees if needed.

name: Pushups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a high plank position with hands under shoulders.
Lower your chest to the floor.
Keep your elbows at a 45-degree angle.
Push back up to the start.
form_cues: Keep your body in a straight line.
injury_prevention_tips: If you feel shoulder pain, widen your hand placement slightly.
Ensure wrists are stacked under shoulders.

name: Pushups (Close and Wide Hand Positions)
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start in a high plank position.
Perform a pushup with hands wide (targets chest).
Move hands close together (under chest) for the next rep (targets triceps).
Alternate between wide and close for the set.
form_cues: Keep elbows tucked on close grip.
Keep elbows flared slightly on wide grip.
common_mistakes: Not adjusting depth based on grip.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't go too wide if you have shoulder issues.
Keep wrists neutral.

name: Pyramid
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place your shins on the edge of a stability ball.
Walk your hands out until the ball is under your shins/feet.
Hold your body in a straight line (like a plank but elevated).
Walk your hands back in to return.
form_cues: Don't let your lower back sag.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a non-slip mat under the ball.
Start with shins on the ball before extending legs.

name: Quad Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your side.
Bend your top knee and grab your ankle with your hand.
Pull your heel toward your glute.
Hold for 20-30 seconds.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't force the stretch.
Use a band if you can't reach your ankle.

name: Quadriceps-SMR
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down with a foam roller under your thighs.
Support your weight on your forearms.
Roll from the bottom of the hip to the top of the knee.
Pause on tender spots for 20-30 seconds.
form_cues: Keep your toes pointed down to target quads.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid the knee joint.
Don't bruise your muscles; use moderate pressure.

name: Rack Pull with Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set pins in a power rack just below knee height.
Attach bands to the bar and the rack to add tension.
Deadlift the bar to lockout.
Lower it back to the pins.
form_cues: Keep your chest up and back flat.
Push the floor away with your feet.
common_mistakes: Letting the bands snap the bar up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure bands are secure.
Don't let the bar bounce off the pins.

name: Rack Pulls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set pins in a power rack just below knee height.
Deadlift the bar from the pins.
Lockout at the top.
Lower it back to the pins.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your shins.
Keep your shoulders slightly in front of the bar.
Drive hips forward at the top.
common_mistakes: Letting the bar drift away from the body.
injury_prevention_tips: Set safety pins correctly.
Don't jerk the weight out of the rack.

name: Rear Leg Raises
beginner_friendly_instructions: Start on all fours (hands and knees).
Keep one knee on the floor.
Lift the other leg straight back until it's level with your hip.
Lower it back down slowly.
common_mistakes: Lifting the leg too high (arching back).
injury_prevention_tips: Keep the movement small and controlled.
Don't lock the working knee.

name: Reverse Band Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a bench in a rack with bands anchored above.
Loop bands over the barbell.
Lie down and unrack the bar (bands should be slack at the top).
Lower to chest and press up (bands assist at the bottom).
common_mistakes: Letting bands snap the bar up.
injury_prevention_tips: Check bands for wear and tear.
Ensure bands are secure.

name: Reverse Band Box Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bands above the bar in a rack.
Place a box behind you at knee height.
Unrack the bar, step back, and squat down to the box.
Pause briefly, then stand up explosively.
injury_prevention_tips: Set the box height so thighs are parallel to the floor.
Ensure bands are secure.

name: Reverse Band Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor bands to the top of the rack and attach to the bar.
Stand with the bar over mid-foot.
Deadlift the bar (bands assist the lockout).
Lower with control.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
injury_prevention_tips: Check bands for integrity.
Don't let the bar drift away from shins.

name: Reverse Band Power Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bands above the bar in a rack.
Unrack the bar and step back.
Squat deep (hips below knees).
Drive up explosively.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure bands are secure.
Don't squat deeper than mobility allows.

name: Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set bands on the rack attached to the bar.
Stand with feet very wide, toes pointed out.
Grip the bar inside your knees.
Deadlift by driving hips forward.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure bands are secure.
Don't let the bar drift away from legs.

name: Reverse Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with an overhand grip (palms down).
Keep elbows tucked into your sides.
Curl the bar up toward your shoulders.
Lower it slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Start light to protect elbows.
Don't hyperextend elbows at the bottom.

name: Reverse Barbell Preacher Curls
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench with an EZ-bar.
Grip the bar with palms facing down.
Rest upper arms on the pad.
Curl the bar up and lower slowly.
form_cues: Keep armpits glued to the pad.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't hyperextend elbows at the bottom.
Stop if you feel forearm cramping.

name: Reverse Cable Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight bar to a low cable pulley. Stand facing the machine, feet shoulder-width apart.
Grab the bar with an overhand grip (palms down), hands about shoulder-width. Tuck your elbows into your sides.
Keeping your elbows pinned to your sides, curl the bar up toward your shoulders by bending your elbows.
Squeeze your forearms and biceps at the top, then slowly lower the bar back down.
form_cues: Squeeze at the top for 1 second.
common_mistakes: Swinging the weight or using momentum.
Letting the elbows drift forward or away from the body.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral to avoid strain.
Control the eccentric (lowering) phase to protect elbow joints.

name: Reverse Crunch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with legs bent at 90 degrees, feet off the floor. Arms are flat by your sides.
Engage your core and lift your hips off the floor, rolling your pelvis toward your ribcage.
Pause briefly when your hips are lifted, then slowly lower back to the starting position.
Keep your neck relaxed and avoid pulling with your arms.
form_cues: Initiate with your lower abs, not momentum.
common_mistakes: Swinging the legs to create momentum.
Lifting the lower back off the floor excessively.
Pulling on the head or neck.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your lower back neutral; avoid excessive arching.
Move slowly to prevent hip flexor overuse.

name: Reverse Flyes
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set an incline bench to about 30 degrees. Lie chest-down, holding light dumbbells.
Let your arms hang straight down, palms facing each other, slight bend in elbows.
Raise your arms out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Pause at the top, then slowly lower back down.
form_cues: Squeeze shoulder blades at the top.
Keep chest pressed into the bench.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing you to shrug.
Lifting too high, engaging traps instead of delts.
Flaring ribs or losing chest contact.
injury_prevention_tips: Use light weights to protect the rotator cuff.
Avoid excessive internal shoulder rotation at the bottom.

name: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie chest-down on a 30-degree incline bench with dumbbells.
Start with arms hanging, palms facing your body.
Lift arms out to the sides while rotating palms forward (external rotation).
Pause when arms are parallel to the floor, then slowly return.
form_cues: Squeeze rear delts at the top.
common_mistakes: Starting with palms already facing forward.
Using momentum to swing the weights.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep weights light to avoid shoulder impingement.
Do not force the range of motion if you feel pinching.

name: Reverse Grip Bent-Over Rows
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width, holding a barbell with an underhand grip (palms up).
Hinge at hips, keeping back flat and chest up, until torso is near parallel to floor.
Pull the bar toward your lower ribcage, squeezing your back muscles.
Lower the bar slowly with control.
common_mistakes: Using biceps too much instead of back muscles.
injury_prevention_tips: Maintain a neutral spine; brace your core.
Choose a weight that allows full control.

name: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight or EZ bar to a high pulley. Face away from the machine.
Grab the bar with an underhand grip (palms up), hands shoulder-width.
Keep elbows tucked into your sides and extend your arms down.
Squeeze triceps at the bottom, then slowly return.
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging the torso.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep shoulders down and relaxed to avoid impingement.
Do not hyperextend elbows at the bottom.

name: Reverse Hyperextension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face-down on a reverse hyper machine, hips off the back pad.
Secure your legs under the pads and hold the handles.
Lift your legs straight back by extending your hips, squeezing glutes and hamstrings.
Lower with control; do not hyperextend your lower back.
form_cues: Lift with hips, not lower back.
common_mistakes: Using too much weight, causing loss of control.
