Slowly release the bar back up to full arm extension.
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar behind the neck.
Using momentum by swinging the torso back.
Not extending arms fully at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Avoid pulling behind the neck to protect cervical spine.
Do not use a grip wider than shoulder width to prevent shoulder impingement.

name: Upper Back-Leg Grab
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit on the floor with legs straight out in front of you.
Bend forward at the hips and reach under your thighs.
Clasp your hands together behind your legs.
Gently pull your chest towards your knees.
form_cues: Pull with your hands, not by shrugging.
common_mistakes: Jerking the stretch instead of easing into it.
injury_prevention_tips: Move slowly into the stretch to avoid muscle strains.
Stop if you feel sharp pain in your lower back.

name: Upper Back Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand or sit tall.
Interlace your fingers and turn your palms outward.
Push your hands straight out away from your body.
Round your upper back and push your hands forward.
common_mistakes: Arching the back instead of rounding it.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not force the stretch; gentle tension is enough.
Keep movements smooth to avoid muscle spasms.

name: Upright Barbell Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a barbell with an overhand grip, hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
Stand tall with the bar resting against your thighs.
Pull the bar straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows.
Lower the bar slowly back down.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
common_mistakes: Using too wide a grip (causes shoulder impingement).
Swinging the torso to generate momentum.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a grip no wider than shoulder width to protect shoulders.
If you feel pinching in the shoulder, stop immediately.

name: Upright Cable Row
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a straight bar to a low cable pulley.
Grab the bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
Pull the bar up towards your chin, driving elbows high.
Lower the bar slowly to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep the bar close to your body.
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar too high (hits the chin).
Using a grip that is too wide.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral to avoid strain.
Avoid excessive momentum to protect the rotator cuff.

name: Upright Row - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on the center of a resistance band.
Grab the handles with an overhand grip, hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
Pull the handles up towards your chin, leading with your elbows.
Lower slowly with control.
form_cues: Keep tension on the band throughout.
common_mistakes: Letting the band snap back down.
Using a grip that is too wide.
injury_prevention_tips: Check the band for tears before using.
Keep your feet planted firmly to avoid slipping.

name: Upward Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Reach both arms straight up to the ceiling.
Clasp your hands together if possible.
Push your hands higher and slightly back.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not force the stretch if you have shoulder pain.
Keep your neck neutral.

name: V-Bar Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the lat pulldown machine and secure your knees.
Grab the V-bar handle with a neutral grip (palms facing each other).
Pull the bar down to your upper chest, driving elbows down.
Return the bar slowly to the starting position.
form_cues: Pull with your elbows, not your arms.
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar behind the neck.
Not fully extending arms at the top.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your wrists straight.
Do not round your lower back.

name: V-Bar Pullup
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set up a V-bar attachment on a pull-up bar (or use parallel bars).
Grab the handles with a neutral grip and hang with arms extended.
Pull your chest towards the bar by driving elbows down and back.
Lower yourself slowly to full extension.
form_cues: Start the pull by depressing shoulder blades.
common_mistakes: Not going to full extension at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Engage your core to prevent swinging.
If you cannot do a full rep, use resistance bands for assistance.

name: Weighted Ball Hyperextension
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie face down on a stability ball with the ball under your hips/stomach.
Anchor your feet against a wall or have a partner hold them.
Hold a weight plate against your chest.
Lift your torso until your body forms a straight line, then lower back down.
common_mistakes: Letting the hips sag off the ball.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep movements controlled to protect the lumbar spine.
Ensure your feet are anchored securely.

name: Weighted Ball Side Bend
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie sideways on a stability ball so your side is supported.
Cross your ankles and keep your feet on the floor.
Hold a weight plate near one side of your head.
Bend sideways at the waist, lowering the weight towards the floor, then lift back up.
form_cues: Keep your movement in a straight line.
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight up.
injury_prevention_tips: Use a light weight to avoid oblique strain.
Keep the movement smooth and controlled.

name: Weighted Bench Dip
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place hands on one bench behind you and feet on another bench in front.
Place a weight plate on your lap (have a partner help).
Lower your body by bending elbows until arms are at 90 degrees.
Press back up to full extension.
form_cues: Keep hips close to the bench.
common_mistakes: Shifting weight to the front of the hands.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not dip below 90 degrees at the elbow.
Ensure benches are stable before starting.

name: Weighted Crunches
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat.
Hold a weight plate against your chest.
Lift your shoulder blades off the floor by contracting your abs.
Lower back down slowly.
form_cues: Keep your lower back on the floor.
common_mistakes: Pulling on the neck with hands.
Lifting the lower back off the floor.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your neck neutral; do not jut it forward.
Keep the weight light to avoid straining the chest/shoulders.

name: Weighted Jump Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Place a light barbell on your back or hold a light dumbbell.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Squat down slightly, then explode upward into a jump.
Land softly with bent knees to absorb the impact.
form_cues: Fully extend hips at the top.
common_mistakes: Using a weight that is too heavy (kills explosiveness).
Letting knees cave inward upon landing.
injury_prevention_tips: Perform on a forgiving surface (rubber mat).
If you have knee issues, substitute with regular squats.

name: Weighted Pull Ups
beginner_friendly_instructions: Attach a weight to a dip belt or hold a dumbbell between your feet.
Grab the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulders.
Pull your chest to the bar, driving elbows down and back.
Lower yourself slowly to full arm extension.
form_cues: Start the pull by retracting shoulder blades.
common_mistakes: Not going to full extension at the bottom.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the weight is secure on the belt.
If you can't do a clean rep, use an assisted pull-up machine.

name: Weighted Sissy Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand upright holding a weight plate against your chest.
Rise up onto your toes.
Lower your torso backwards while keeping your knees in line with your toes.
Use your quads to pull yourself back up.
form_cues: Keep your knees tracking over toes.
Go down until thighs are parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Letting knees drift too far forward past toes.
Using momentum instead of quad control.
injury_prevention_tips: Hold onto a support with one hand if balance is an issue.
Start without weight to master the knee tracking.

name: Weighted Sit-Ups - With Bands
beginner_friendly_instructions: Anchor a resistance band behind you (low point).
Lie on your back (floor or decline bench) and hold the band ends near your chest.
Sit up fully, engaging your abs.
Control the descent back to the start.
form_cues: Pull your elbows forward as you sit up.
Keep the tension on the band constant.
common_mistakes: Pulling on your neck with your hands.
Letting the band pull you down too fast.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure the band anchor is secure.
Keep your spine neutral; avoid excessive rounding.

name: Weighted Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand on two benches with feet shoulder-width apart.
Attach a weighted belt around your waist with weight hanging between your legs.
Squat down by bending knees and pushing hips back.
Drive back up through your heels.
form_cues: Keep your knees in line with toes.
common_mistakes: Letting heels lift off the benches.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure benches are stable and non-slip.
Start with light weight to adjust to the balance requirement.

name: Wide-Grip Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a flat bench with feet flat on the floor.
Grab the bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width.
Unrack the bar and lower it to your mid-chest.
Press the bar back up to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep elbows tucked at about 45-60 degrees.
Drive your feet into the floor.
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out to 90 degrees (shoulder strain).
Bouncing the bar off the chest.
injury_prevention_tips: Have a spotter when lifting heavy.
Keep wrists straight to avoid hyperextension.

name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Bench Press
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench with feet secured.
Grab the bar with a wide grip.
Lower the bar to your lower chest.
Press the bar back up.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure leg rollers are secure.
Don't use a grip wider than what is comfortable for your shoulders.

name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Pullover
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on a decline bench with legs secured.
Hold a barbell with a wide grip above your chest.
Lower the bar in an arc behind your head until arms are parallel to the floor.
Pull the bar back over to the starting position.
form_cues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows.
Move only at the shoulder joint.
common_mistakes: Bending elbows too much (turns into a tricep extension).
Dropping the bar too low (risk to shoulder capsule).
injury_prevention_tips: Use a lighter weight than you think you need.
Stop immediately if you feel shoulder pain.

name: Wide-Grip Lat Pulldown
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the lat pulldown machine and secure knees.
Grab the bar with a grip wider than shoulder-width.
Pull the bar down to your upper chest.
Return the bar slowly to the top.
common_mistakes: Pulling the bar behind the neck.
injury_prevention_tips: Do not pull behind the neck.
Ensure the grip isn't so wide that it hurts the shoulders.

name: Wide-Grip Pulldown Behind The Neck
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at the lat pulldown machine.
Grab the bar with a wide grip.
Pull the bar down to the back of your neck.
Return the bar slowly up.
common_mistakes: Dropping the head forward too much.
injury_prevention_tips: This exercise carries a high risk of shoulder and neck injury. Proceed with extreme caution.
Use very light weight.
Consider substituting with standard front pulldowns.

name: Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up
beginner_friendly_instructions: Grab a pull-up bar with a wide overhand grip.
Hang with arms extended.
Pull your chest towards the bar (pulling 'back' rather than 'down').
Lower yourself slowly.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have adequate shoulder mobility.
Keep wrists neutral.

name: Wide-Grip Standing Barbell Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a barbell with a wide grip (hands outside shoulders).
Keep elbows tucked at your sides.
Curl the bar up towards your shoulders.
Lower the bar slowly.
form_cues: Keep elbows pinned to your sides.
common_mistakes: Swinging the torso to lift the weight.
Using a grip that is too wide (wrist strain).
injury_prevention_tips: Keep wrists neutral.
Don't lock out elbows abruptly at the bottom.

name: Wide Stance Barbell Squat
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell on a rack at shoulder height.
Duck under the bar and rest it on your upper back.
Step out and set feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly out.
Squat down by pushing hips back and bending knees, then drive back up.
form_cues: Push knees out in line with toes.
Keep your weight centered over mid-foot.
injury_prevention_tips: Keep your core braced to protect your spine.
Ensure your knees track over your toes.

name: Wind Sprints
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar with arms extended.
Lift one knee towards your chest.
Quickly switch legs, bringing the other knee up.
Continue alternating in a running motion.
common_mistakes: Swinging your body to generate momentum.
injury_prevention_tips: Ensure you have a secure grip.
If you have shoulder issues, perform on the floor instead.

name: Windmills
beginner_friendly_instructions: Lie on your back with arms out to the sides.
Lift one leg straight up.
Lower it across your body towards the opposite hand.
Return to center and repeat.
common_mistakes: Lifting the opposite shoulder off the floor.
Bending the knee of the moving leg.
injury_prevention_tips: Don't force the stretch if you feel hip pinching.
Keep your neck relaxed.

name: World's Greatest Stretch
beginner_friendly_instructions: Step into a deep lunge with your right foot forward.
Place your left hand on the floor inside your right foot.
Rotate your right arm up towards the ceiling.
Straighten your right leg and sink your hips down.
form_cues: Keep your front knee tracking over the ankle.
common_mistakes: Letting the front knee collapse inward.
injury_prevention_tips: Use yoga blocks for support if you can't reach the floor.
Keep your movements smooth.

name: Wrist Circles
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand tall with arms out to the sides at shoulder height.
Make fists with your hands.
Rotate your wrists in large circles.
Reverse direction after a set number of reps.
form_cues: Keep arms parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Going too fast and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up the wrists gently before adding speed.
Stop if you feel sharp pain.

name: Wrist Roller
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding a wrist roller with arms extended.
Roll one wrist forward, then the other, to pull the weight up.
Once at the top, reverse the motion to lower the weight.
Keep arms extended throughout.
form_cues: Keep arms parallel to the floor.
common_mistakes: Dropping the weight too fast on the way down.
injury_prevention_tips: Start with a light weight.
Keep wrists neutral; don't bend them awkwardly.

name: Wrist Rotations with Straight Bar
beginner_friendly_instructions: Hold a light dumbbell or barbell with an overhand grip.
Keep your forearm resting on a bench or your thigh.
Rotate the weight up and down using only your wrist.
Switch hands after one set.
injury_prevention_tips: Warm up wrists thoroughly.
Use light weight to avoid tendonitis.

name: Zercher Squats
beginner_friendly_instructions: Set a barbell in a rack at lower chest height.
Cross your arms and cradle the barbell in the crooks of your elbows.
Stand up, step out, and set feet shoulder-width apart.
Squat down deep, keeping your torso upright, then drive back up.
common_mistakes: Letting the elbows drop (bar slides down).
injury_prevention_tips: Pad the bar with a towel if it hurts your arms.
Keep your core extremely tight to protect your spine.

name: Zottman Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides, palms facing forward.
Curl the weights up, keeping palms up (supinated).
At the top, rotate your wrists so palms face down (pronated).
Lower the weights with palms facing down, then rotate back at the bottom.
common_mistakes: Rotating too fast and losing control.
injury_prevention_tips: Use lighter weight than a standard curl.
Keep wrists neutral during rotation.

name: Zottman Preacher Curl
beginner_friendly_instructions: Sit at a preacher bench holding dumbbells.
Start with palms facing down (pronated).
Lower the weights, then rotate palms up (supinated).
Curl the weights up, then rotate back to palms down at the top.
form_cues: Keep armpits glued to the pad.
Rotate smoothly at the bottom and top.
Keep your chest against the pad.
common_mistakes: Lifting your armpit off the pad.
Using a weight that is too heavy to control the rotation.
injury_prevention_tips: Focus on the eccentric (lowering) phase.
Ensure the bench is stable.
